Title: Individuality and Reproducibility of Striae on Plastic Wad Components Fired from a Sawed-Off Shotgun
Affiliations: Kansas Bureau of Investigation, Firearm & Toolmark Section, Kansas City, Kansas
Authors with affiliations: Kansas Bureau of Investigation, Firearm & Toolmark Section, Kansas City, Kansas
Author Keywords: Published case reports document the identifications of fired plastic wad components to the barrels of sawed-off shotguns. These identifications are based on striae located on the bearing surface of the wads as a result of burrs left behind by the tool used to cut the barrel. This study evaluates the reproducibility and individuality of these striations through the microscopic examination of plastic wads fired from a shotgun after a hacksaw has been used to cut off portions of the barrel. Methods for testing, microscopic examination, and documentation were developed that may aid examiners when faced with such evidence in future casework.
Index Keywords: Examination of Plastic Wads, Hacksaw Blades, Lighting Methods, Sawed-off Shotgun, Winchester Drylok Super Steel Ammunition

Title: Firearms Identification - Sometimes All Is Not As It Seems
Authors with affiliations: A Technical Report By Sergeant Gerard Dutton, Tasmania Police, Hobart, Tasmania, AUSTRALIA.
Author Keywords: There are many different ways to report our findings after carrying out various field and laboratory examinations. AFTE members from laboratories who participate in the Collaborative Testing Services (Virginia USA) Proficiency Tests will be aware from the Final Reports, just how many different ways hundreds of individuals can report exactly the same conclusion. A shooting murder investigated recently by the author highlighted some issues in regards to the technically correct way to report upon comparative examination results. The circumstances of the case and the evidence recovered dictated what was required in the report and this is discussed for the benefit and consideration of AFTE members if a similar situation is encountered in their casework.
Index Keywords: Breech bolt, Firearms identification, Firing pin, Reporting, Stirling model 14 rifle, Terminology.

Title: Accidental/Unusual Discharge of a Jennings J-22

Title: Fibres on Bullets After Firing Through Textiles
Once Fired, Twice Fired, More? A Novel Method for Assessing the Number of Firings of Shotshells with Plastic Bodies
Authors with affiliations: Lucien C. Haag, Forensic Science Services, Inc., Carefree, AZ
Author Keywords: A pattern is produced on the interior surface of the plastic tube in modern shotshells during the discharge process that directly relates to the number of times the shell has been fired. This "alligator" pattern has unique characteristics and is generated by the erosive effects of the hot powder gases rushing out the shell during discharge. The pattern can be quantified and associated with the number of times the shell has been fired.
Index Keywords: shotguns, shotshells, reloads, gun bursts, alligator pattern

Title: A Suicide Bomber's Weapon
Authors with affiliations: Uri Argaman, B.Sc., Ezra Shoshani, B. Sc. and Asne Klein, M.Sc., Division of Identification & Forensic Science (D.I.F.S.), Israel Police National Headquarters, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: In 1997 a suicide bomber carrying a bomb and a pistol, denoted his explosives and exploded himself in the heart of Downtown Jerusalem. From the pistol parts that were recovered, it was found that the pistol was an FN Hi -Power semi -automatic, 9 mm Luger caliber. This report shows the identification of the exploded pistol parts and ammunition.

Author Keywords: An unusual M-16 assault rifle, 5.56X45 mm (.223 REM) caliber, was seized from a suspect. The assault rifle was an M-16, model A1, which had been professionally shortened to an overall length of 57 cm by trimming some of its parts, especially the barrel and the butt-stock. This was done mainly to enable the concealment of this "subcarbine". This report shows the alterations to the rifle's parts and the resulting changes in its functionality.

Authors: Nedivi L., Giverts P., Shoshani E., Brauner P.
Title: The Magal - A New Weapon in the Fight on Urban Terrorism
Authors with affiliations: A Case Report By Lior Nedivi, Israel National Police, Pavel Giverts & Ezra Shoshani, Weapons Identification Laboratory, DIFS, Israel Police National Headquarters, and Paul Brauner, DIFS, Israel National Police Headquarters
Author Keywords: This report describes the development of a new, longrange weapon, specially designed for police use. To our knowledge, no similar weapon has ever been employed by any other police force. In light of the special demands, placed on the police in Israel, it was decided that a new weapon was needed. This firearm, the MAGAL, can be classified as an urban weapon, as this is the environment in which it was designed to be used. Historical aspects of the use of long-range weapons by the police are discussed. The development of the MAGAL, together with technical specifications of this new weapon, are also presented.
Index Keywords: MAGAL, urban weapon,.30 carbine, 7.62X33mm, urban terrorism

Title: Fire Control Part Variations in Colt M16/AR15 and Sporter Type Rifles
Authors with affiliations: By: Christopher R. Bartocci, Wisconsin State Crime Laboratory, Milwaukee, WI
Author Keywords: Since the AR15/M16 weapon system came out in the early 1960's, Colt Firearms/ Colt's Manufacturing Company. Inc has made several changes in their fire-control components. In the beginning, when the semi-automatic versions were first put on the market, the fire control parts (bolt carrier, hammer, disconnector, trigger and selector) were just slightly modified or in some cases not changed at all for semi-automatic fire only. In this study I will examine more than five generations of fire control components of both selective fire and semi-automatic rifles. I will examine the first production AR15 SP1 right up to the current configuration Colt is producing. It is important to know what these parts look like as well as that some of these parts were installed by Colt during manufacturing and were not added by the owner.
Index Keywords: M16, M16A1, M16A2, M4, AR15, Colt Sporter, Colt Match, Post-Ban Colt Sporter, Full Auto Conversion, Fire Control Group Differences

Title: Full-Auto Intratec or Not
Authors with affiliations: Susan Allen and Travis Spinder, Southwestern Institute of Forensic Sciences, Dallas, TX
Author Keywords: The purpose of this article is to reiterate a popular modification of the 9mm Intratec Tec 9 pistol to fullautomatic fire and to show that this modification can be unreliable. This could cause problems for Firearms Examiners during the initial examination of the Intratec firearm in which no modifications may be detected. Precautions should be taken whenever test firing one of these firearms.

Authors: Shoshani E., Argaman U., Hocherman G., Koffman A.
Title: Metal Chip Marks on Fired Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: Ezra Shoshani, B.Sc. (Eng.), Uri Argaman, M.B.A., B.Sc. (Eng.), Gil Hocherman, M.Sc. (Eng.), Avi Koffman, B.Sc. (Eng.), Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel Police National Headquarters, Jerusa
Author Keywords: This report presents a case in which a unique mark with a general imprint in the shape of a "half-moon" was found on the outside walls of 7.62x39 mm fired cartridge cases. These cartridge cases came from the test-firing of a seized Kalashnikov AK-47 assault-rifle, submitted to the Israel Police Firearms Identification Laboratory for examination. These marks had individual characteristics that were positively compared with each other, leading to the conclusion that the marks had the same source. This report will show that the source of the marks was not from an integral part of the weapon. The metal chip in the shape of a half-moon was present in the AK-47 assault-rifle chamber during firing, imprinting marks on test-fired cartridge cases in a different orientation every time the weapon was fired. The chip was finally ejected during one of the test firings and was compared to the marks found on the fired cartridge cases. The question then arose: Can a firearms examiner rely upon positive comparison of marks with individual charateristics which are not from an integral part of the weapon? This question will be discussed in this report.
Index Keywords: metal chip, cartridge case, individual characteristics

Title: Rivet Impression in Bullet Nose
Authors with affiliations: Edward Wallace, Bexar County Criminal Investigation Laboratory, San Antonio, TX
Author Keywords: A case recently submitted to our laboratory involved an armed robbery in which a store owner was shot multiple times. One of the bullets recovered at autopsy exhibited some unusual characteristics on the nose. Upon closer examination the peculiarities revealed themselves to be lettering from a pocket rivet that had been struck and driven into the victim. The lettering could clearly be seen to spell 'Lauren Jeans', the brand of the jeans. The rivet was also recovered at autopsy and submitted for examination. A physical fit between the rivet and the bullet was achieved.
Index Keywords: Bullet Nose, Impact, Ralph Lauren Jeans, Rivet

Authors with affiliations: Christopher R. Bartocci, Wisconsin State Crime Laboratory, Milwaukee
Author Keywords: There are class characteristics present on a fired 7.62x39mm cartridge case which will determine and identify what type of weapon system they were fired from (SKS or AK47/AKM). This article will show how those markings are made and in what location of the fired cartridge case they will be found.

Title: Identification of Polygonal Barrel Sub-Family Characteristics
Authors with affiliations: By: Gil Hocherman, Pavel Giverts, Ezra Shosani, Division of Identification and Forensic Science, Israel Police National H.Q., Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: A method was developed to distinguish between bullets from two sub-groups of polygonal rifling from Glock, Heckler-Koch and Jericho. Tests conducted showed that formalized training was necessary to obtain valid results even with experienced firearms examiners.

Title: An Interesting Magazine Mark
Authors with affiliations: A Case Report By John R. Clark, Monroe County Dept. of Public Safety Crime Laboratory, Rochester, NY
Author Keywords: A 32 Auto caliber, Beretta model 3032 Tomcat was recently submitted to the author's laboratory along with one fired 32 Auto caliber cartridge case. Upon examination of the fired cartridge case an unusual mark was discovered on the head outside of the primer area. After further examination it was determined that the mark was created by a weld in the magazine.
Index Keywords: Beretta Model 3032, breech face, magazine, magazine mark, striated, weld

Title: Consecutively Manufactured Ruger P-89 Slides
Authors with affiliations: By: Amy C. Coody, Kansas Bureau of Investigation, Topeka, Kansas
Author Keywords: Ten consecutively manufactured Ruger P89 pistol slides and one frame were acquired from the manufacturer for examination and testing. The slides were mounted on the frame and test-fired to obtain cartridge cases for comparison. Breechface marks on the test-fired cartridge cases were compared for class and individual characteristics that resulted from the manufacturing processes. The parallel striations evident on each test-fired cartridge case were a product of filing of the breechface. Granular detail exhibited by some of the test-fired cartridge cases was a result of bead blasting of the slide; tests from two of the slides display marks that correspond to burrs found around the periphery of the firing pin aperture. It was found that the slides can be identified based on these breechface marks.
Index Keywords: Bead blasting; Breechface shear; Chamfering; Consecutive Breechface(s); Consecutive Breechface Marks; Consecutive Ruger slides; Filing; Identification; Individual characteristics

Title: Validation Study of Electrochemical Rifling
Authors with affiliations: By: Charles S. DeFrance and Michael D. Van Arsdale, Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, D.C.
Author Keywords: Electrochemical machining is being used by Smith & Wesson to rifle many of its revolver barrels. This paper provides a description of this manufacturing process and a study that was conducted to evaluate whether or not these barrels will mark bullets in a repeatable and unique manner. This validation study of firearms/toolmarks identification as it applies to electrochemical rifling found that this manufacturing technique does produce unique, reproducible, and identifiable microscopic marks.
Index Keywords: electrochemical machining, electrochemical rifling, ECR, validation study

Title: Serial Number "Restoration" on a Colt All American Model 2000
Authors with affiliations: Michael Cooper, Southern Illinois Forensic Science Centre, Carbondale, Illinois
Author Keywords: The serial number of a Colt All American model 2000 was discovered and "restored" in a unique way. The serial number plate was removed and the back side cast with "Mikrosil". The cast revealed the serial number of the firearm.

Authors: Shoshani E., Klain A., Argaman U.
Title: Altering a Serial Number
Authors with affiliations: Ezra Shoshani, B.Sc, Asny Klain, Uri Argaman, B.Sc, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (D.I.F.S.), Israel National Police, Police Headquarters, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: This report introduces a case in which the parts of a CZ 75 semi-automatic pistol were symmetrically changed, almost without effecting the outside appearance of the firearm, to give it a new identity with another serial number. The serial number change was effected in such a way that only a very careful examination by a trained eye, was able to discover and trace the alterations. The purpose of this article is to alert forensic firearm and toolmark examiners of this unique case.
Index Keywords: serial number, CZ 75, reprint, alteration

Title: The Restoration of Obliterated Laser-Etched Firearm Identifiers by Conventional and Alternative Decryption Methods
Authors with affiliations: Gregory S. Klees, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, Washington Forensic Science Laboratory, Rockville, Maryland
Author Keywords: This article reviews the restoration of obiterated laser-etched firearm serial number and barcode identifiers by using conventional processing and automatic decryption methods. Additionally, procedures on how to manually decrypt Code 39 firearm barcodes are detailed. The Code 39 barcode is the type presently used on Smith & Wesson Sigma series pistols as part of the serial number identifier. Because this type barcode is now being laser-etched and tested as a firearm component in Europe, their prevalent use as a firearm marking(s) in the future is very probable.
Index Keywords: serial number, restoration, barcode, laser etching, decryption

Authors: Shakir A., Koehler S.A., Wecht C.H.
Title: A review of nail gun suicides and an atypical case report
Affiliations: Allegheny County Coroner's Office, 542 Fourth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15219, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shakir, A., Allegheny County Coroner's Office, 542 Fourth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15219, United States; Koehler, S.A., Allegheny County Coroner's Office, 542 Fourth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15219, United States; Wecht, C.H., Allegheny County Coroner's Office, 542 Fourth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15219, United States
Author Keywords: The nail gun was designed as a powerful industrial tool to drive nails into various hard surfaces with ease. Serious injuries associated with the tool are uncommon and deaths are rare. Unintentional injuries normally occur from misuse of the tool or from ricocheting nails. The intentional use of a nail gun to commit suicide is unusual. This paper will review successful and unsuccessful suicide attempts by use of a nail gun. We will present an atypical case of suicide committed with a nail gun by a 46-year-old depressed male investigated by the Allegheny County Coroner's Office in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania in April 2002. This case reports for the first time a unique pathological finding of a ring of bone traveling with the nail, which has not been seen in wounds of the head caused by other types of projectiles.
Index Keywords: Atypical case; Forensic science; Nail gun; Ring of bone; Suicide

Title: Dangerous Walking Stick
Authors with affiliations: Dangerous Walking Stick
Author Keywords: This article describes an improvised firearm in the shape of a walking stick. This firearm fires 5.56 x 45mm caliber (.223 Rem) ammunition, and was found to be both accurate and lethal. Muzzle velocities were found to be consistent, at approximately 256 m/sec (~830 ft./ sec.).
Index Keywords: weapon alteration, homemade weapon, walking stick, cane, concealed firearm, zip-gun

Title: The Construction and Relative Efficiency of a Homemade Sound Suppressor vs. a Commercial Mode
Authors with affiliations: Jennifer Grandy, Strathclyde University, Master's Intern, Indianapolis-Marion County Forensic Services Agency, Indianapolis, Indiana
Author Keywords: A select fire SWD M11/9mm submachine pistol was fired in three modes; unsuppressed, suppressed with a commercially manufactured sound suppresser and suppressed with a homemade model. For each shot fired the sound reduction, velocity of the projectile and relative accuracy were measured. Identical experiments were carried out using subsonic and supersonic ammunition to illustrate the aspects of sound due to the bullet travelling a speeds greater than 1125ft/s (343m/s). The purpose was to determine not only what effect each silencer had on the attributes of discharge but also to determine if there is a marked difference as a result of using a professional suppresser as opposed to more crude model. The professional suppresser used was a Jonathon Arthur Ciener Inc. model SM10/9mm-47. A major part of the project included the construction of a silencer for use in the study. The home made silencer was constructed in the lab for the expressed purpose of the study herein. Common hardware items were used and lightly machined to fit specifications. Aluminum tubing, metal washers and rubber baffles were the primary components involved. No specific relationship between sound and velocity could be found. The home made silencer reduced sound more efficiently, however, the Ciener was more accurate and managed to cut noise while increasing velocity. The homemade suppresser slowed the supersonic shots to speeds below that of sound.
Index Keywords: Ciener, suppressor, baffles, precursor wave, blow-by, supersonic crack, jet noise, muzzle blast

Title: Dieseling of Airguns Using Commonly Available Fuels
Authors with affiliations: Robert Caunt, Vancouver Police Department Forensic Firearm Unit, Vancouver, Canada
Author Keywords: Introducing a variety of flammable liquids into the cylinder of a spring piston air rifle and measuring the velocities of the projectiles confirmed the phenomenon of dieseling. It was found that certain fuels will spontaneously diesel, yielding a boost in velocity of as much as twice the standard velocity. The occurrence of dieseling is dependent on a number of factors, but most importantly the properties of the fuel. Some fuels spontaneously combust, while others need a secondary source of ignition. Pellet weight, pellet fit, and over-lubrication of the piston causing dieseling have implications for forensic testing of airguns. As with firearms, when possible the examiner should test the same gun and ammunition combination as was used to commit a crime. This is the only way to assure accurate velocity and energy determination. This paper was presented at the 33rd annual AFTE Training Seminar, San Antonio, Texas on May 29, 2002.
Index Keywords: Adiabatic compression, airgun, airgun dieseling, Barakuda device, detonation, diesel, overlubrication, secondary ignition, timing

Authors: Hartig J.S., Najafi-Shoushtari S.H., Grüne I., Yan A., Ellington A.D., Famulok M.
Title: Air rifle injury with an entrance through the nose: A case report and review of the literature
Affiliations: Kekulé Institut f�r Organische Chemie und Biochemie, University of Bonn, Gerhard-Domagk-Strasse 1, 53121 Bonn, Germany; Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, ICMB A4800/MBB 3.448BA, 26th and Speedway, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hartig, J.S., Kekulé Institut f�r Organische Chemie und Biochemie, University of Bonn, Gerhard-Domagk-Strasse 1, 53121 Bonn, Germany; Najafi-Shoushtari, S.H., Kekulé Institut f�r Organische Chemie und Biochemie, University of Bonn, Gerhard-Domagk-Strasse 1, 53121 Bonn, Germany; Grüne, I., Kekulé Institut f�r Organische Chemie und Biochemie, University of Bonn, Gerhard-Domagk-Strasse 1, 53121 Bonn, Germany; Yan, A., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, ICMB A4800/MBB 3.448BA, 26th and Speedway, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Ellington, A.D., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, ICMB A4800/MBB 3.448BA, 26th and Speedway, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Famulok, M., Kekulé Institut f�r Organische Chemie und Biochemie, University of Bonn, Gerhard-Domagk-Strasse 1, 53121 Bonn, Germany
Author Keywords: A case of attempted homicide is reported where a 31-year-old woman was shot in the left nostril with a pellet from an air rifle. The projectile channel reconstruction showed penetration of the nasal septum, the maxillary and sphenoid cavities and the dura mater, with the pellet finally lodging in the anterior cranial fossa between the sinus cavernosus and the internal carotid artery. The patient was finally discharged from hospital in a good physical condition without any neurological symptoms. Although the muzzle velocity of the air rifle was within the legal limits, the present case demonstrates the potential lethality of air weapons considering the site of entrance of the pellet.
Index Keywords: Air rifle; Gunshot injury; Potential lethality

Authors: Bock H., Neu M., Betz P., Seidl S.
Title: Unusual craniocerebral injury caused by a pneumatic nail gun
Affiliations: Department of Legal Medicine, University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Universitätsstrasse 22, 91054 Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bock, H., Department of Legal Medicine, University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Universitätsstrasse 22, 91054 Erlangen, Germany; Neu, M.; Betz, P., Department of Legal Medicine, University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Universitätsstrasse 22, 91054 Erlangen, Germany; Seidl, S., Department of Legal Medicine, University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Universitätsstrasse 22, 91054 Erlangen, Germany
Author Keywords: A man was found unconscious near a ladder in a house. After resuscitation he was brought to a hospital and X-rays of the skull showed that two 12-cm long nails had completely penetrated the cranial cavity. The nails were operatively removed and after treatment for 5 weeks, the patient was transferred to a rehabilitation centre with a decreasing hemiparesis on the left side and general deterioration and then, after an attempted suicide to a psychiatric hospital. The perforating cranio-cerebral injury from a pneumatic nail gun known to reach only low muzzle velocities is a very unusual finding.
Index Keywords: Cranial injury; Nail gun

Authors: Anders S., Junge M., Schulz F., Püschel K.
Title: Cutaneous current marks due to a stun gun injury
Affiliations: Institute for Legal Medicine, University of Hamburg, Butenfeld 34, 22529 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Anders, S., Institute for Legal Medicine, University of Hamburg, Butenfeld 34, 22529 Hamburg, Germany; Junge, M., Institute for Legal Medicine, University of Hamburg, Butenfeld 34, 22529 Hamburg, Germany; Schulz, F., Institute for Legal Medicine, University of Hamburg, Butenfeld 34, 22529 Hamburg, Germany; Püschel, K., Institute for Legal Medicine, University of Hamburg, Butenfeld 34, 22529 Hamburg, Germany
Author Keywords: Histological changes of the skin following electrical injury with a stun gun have rarely been described. We report the case of a 61 year-old man who died after having been tortured with a stun gun during a robbery. At autopsy two reddish, dot-like lesions where found on the chest and histological examination revealed electric current-related changes. Only a few reports concerning micromorphological cutaneous changes following stun gun injury have been reported; therefore further investigations concerning the frequency and type of histological findings due to stun gun injuries will be necessary in order to provide sufficient characteristic data for a conclusive interpretation.
Index Keywords: Current mark; Electrocution; Forensic histopathology; Forensic science; Stun gun; Taser

Title: What's Good For Them Is Good For Us': Outside Influences on the Adoption of Incapacitate Sprays by the British Police,
Authors with affiliations: John W. Buttle Centre for Comparative Criminology and Criminal Justice, School of Social Science, University of Wales, Bangor, Gwynedd LL57 2DG, UK
Author Keywords: The United States and to a lesser extent France have a history of using incapacitant sprays and other non-lethal weapons for law enforcement purposes. This was taken into consideration when violent assaults on police officers led to the eventual decision to arm British constables routinely with CS spray. Many police officers in the United Kingdom put their faith in research conducted in these countries. They assumed their greater experience regarding incapacitant sprays would lend support to this policy. This article examines the outside influences involved in the adoption of incapacitant sprays in the England and Wales. It discusses the research conducted on health and operational matters concerning incapacitant sprays as well as identifying the policy objectives of adopting incapacitant sprays. The article challenges the underlying assumptions on which these policies are based. It will question the wisdom of adopting incapacitant sprays for policing purposes and consider the implications of adopting other non-lethal weapons.

Title: Stun gun injuries in the abuse and death of a seven-month-old infant
Authors with affiliations: Turner, M.S.; Jumbelic, M.I.
Author Keywords: The author autopsied a seven-month-old infant who was shocked repeatedly with a stun gun by his foster mother, in an attempt by the foster mother to get the infant to stop crying. The stun gun injuries were round, well-circumscribed, erythematous macular lesions, which were found in pairs. The lesions were 2 in. apart, and were found to match the distance between the electrodes of the stun gun found in the foster mother's purse. Based on the electrical output of the stun gun, the small size of the infant, location of stun gun discharge, and the decreased resistance of the infant's skin, it can be concluded that the stun gun injury is responsible for the infant's death.
Index Keywords: Electrocution; Forensic science; Infant homicide; Stun gun deaths; Stun gun homicide; Stun gun injuries
Correspondence Address: article; case report; child abuse; child death; electric shock; electrode; erythema; homicide; human; infant; male; priority journal

Title: Skin Perforation and Skin Simulants
Authors with affiliations: Michael G. Haag, Albuquerque Police Crime Lab, Lucien C. Haag, Forensic Science Services, Inc., Carefree , AZ
Author Keywords: Air guns and BB guns are occasionally involved in injuries usually resulting from the unsupervised use (or misuse) of these relatively low powered guns. These incidents frequently give rise to questions regarding the injury-producing capabilities of such guns. Such inquiries often start with the issue of skin perforation. These guns are available in calibers from .177 inch to .25 in. with projectiles consisting of .173 in. steel spheres to soft lead projectiles in a variety of shapes and weights in .177, .20, .22 and .25 caliber. The nature of their ammunition and the ability to regulate and select velocity to a greater extent than bulleted cartridges makes them useful in assessing threshold velocities for skin penetration and perforation. This paper examines the threshold velocity necessary to perforate skin and skin simulants by selected projectiles and a proposed method for calibrating skin simulants. Additionally, the effect of nose shape on the low velocity terminal ballistic performance of some of these small caliber projectiles is presented.
Index Keywords: air gun, BB, BB gun, pellet, pellet gun, wound ballistics, skin penetration, perforation, threshold velocity, velocity loss

Authors: Ng’walali P.M., Ohtsu Y., Muraoka N., Tsunenari S.
Title: Unusual homicide by air gun with pellet embolisation
Affiliations: Department of Forensic Medicine, Kumamoto University School of Medicine, 2-2-1 Honjyo, Kumamoto 860-0811, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ng’walali, P.M., Department of Forensic Medicine, Kumamoto University School of Medicine, 2-2-1 Honjyo, Kumamoto 860-0811, Japan; Ohtsu, Y., Department of Forensic Medicine, Kumamoto University School of Medicine, 2-2-1 Honjyo, Kumamoto 860-0811, Japan; Muraoka, N., Department of Forensic Medicine, Kumamoto University School of Medicine, 2-2-1 Honjyo, Kumamoto 860-0811, Japan; Tsunenari, S., Department of Forensic Medicine, Kumamoto University School of Medicine, 2-2-1 Honjyo, Kumamoto 860-0811, Japan
Author Keywords: A homicidal case by an air gun involving a 73-year-old woman who was found dead in her home is described. At autopsy, two gunshot wounds were observed on the left anterior chest and the right back. There was neither exit wound nor powder burns. The fatal pellet, 0.9g and 5.5mm diameter, penetrated the left anterior chest and the heart to cause cardiac tamponade (200ml) before lodging in the left subclavian artery. Death was due to cardiac tamponade.This case has exhibited two rare phenomena: homicide by an air gun and pellet embolisation. This is the first homicide case by use of air gun in Japan and demonstrates that although it may be rare, air guns can be used as potential homicidal weapons. This experience will alert our society and others on the potential hazards of air guns we have tended to regard as toys. © 2001 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Air gun; Forensic pathology; Homicide; Pellet embolisation

Title: Compositional variation in bullet lead manufacture
Affiliations: Forensic Science Research Unit, FBI Laboratory, FBI Academy, Quantico, VA, United States; Chemistry Unit, FBI Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koons, R.D., Forensic Science Research Unit, FBI Laboratory, FBI Academy, Quantico, VA, United States; Grant, D.M., Chemistry Unit, FBI Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Author Keywords: The concentrations of antimony, copper, tin, arsenic, silver, bismuth, and cadmium in lead alloys produced by two smelters and one ammunition manufacturer were determined using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry. These element concentrations were used to measure the variations in composition of lead products that result from various processes involved in the manufacture of lead projectiles. In general, when a pot containing molten lead is used to cast a number of objects, these objects are similar, although not necessarily analytically indistinguishable in their elemental compositions. In each subsequent step in the processing of lead at the smelter and at the ammunition manufacturer, the size of an individual homogeneous melt of lead decreases as more distinct compositions are formed as a result of remelting and mixing of sources, including lead scrap. The ammunition manufacturer in this study produced at least 10 compositionally distinguishable groups of bullet wire in a 19.7-h period. The largest group could potentially be used to produce a maximum of 1.3 million compositionally indistinguishable 40 grain bullets.
Index Keywords: Bullet; Criminalistics; Elemental analysis; Forensic science; ICP-AES; Lead analysis; Trace evidence
Correspondence Address: alloy; antimony; arsenic; bismuth; cadmium; copper; lead; silver; tin; article; atomic emission spectrometry; ballistics; bullet; chemical analysis; forensic science; priority journal; sampling; smelter

Authors: Tulleners F., Randich E., Giusto M.
Title: Vickers Harness Values of Selected 40 S&W Primers
Authors with affiliations: Vickers Harness Values of Selected 40 S&W Primers
Author Keywords: A study was conducted to evaluate the Vickers microhardness of primers from five different brands of 40 S&W unfired cartridges from major manufacturers. Primer hardness is affected by the structure and the composition of the brass used in its manufacture and by the nickel plating if one is used. This study measured the Vickers microhardness and the thickness of the primers. Nickel platings increased the apparent microhardness of the primers. Differences were found in the average microhardness values of the underlying brass of the primers, and these differences were clearly attributable to the different grain sizes of the brass.
Index Keywords: Nickel Plating Primer Hardness, Vickers Hardness

Title: The Exterior and Terminal Ballistics of 00 Buckshot
Authors with affiliations: The Exterior and Terminal Ballistics of 00 Buckshot
Author Keywords: The use of 00 buckshot in hunting and law enforcement as well as its occasional use in criminal enterprises gives rise to a number of interesting exterior and terminal ballistic questions not readily obtained from textbooks or journals. While relatively close range determinations derived from pattern testing are common and well known, the exterior and terminal ballistics of the individual pellets can be of interest insofar as questions regarding lethality and injury-producing capabilities at ranges on the order of 50 yards and more. Two techniques (Doppler radar and the Oehler M43 PBL system) were used to study the exterior ballistic performance of standard .33 caliber 00 buckshot. The effects of variations in the surface texture and topography of individual buckshot pellets were also studied and found to only have a small effect on exterior ballistic performance. The two techniques gave comparable results for the exterior ballistic performance of buckshot pellets of the same weight and surface texture and allowed a useful ballistic coefficient to be derived for 00 buckshot pellets. This value is useful in future casework for estimating down range velocities of fired buckshot pellets and in evaluating the potential for injury by these projectiles at relatively long ranges. Standard 10%w/w ordnance gelatin at 40C with and without a skin simulant was used to study the wound ballistic aspects of these soft lead spheres at selected impact velocities. The plot of penetration vs. impact velocity was prepared from this work is useful in estimating range of fire for soft tissue gunshot wounds produced by distant fire of 00 buckshot pellets.
Index Keywords: buckshot, exterior ballistics, terminal ballistics, maximum range, ballistic coefficient, Doppler radar, Oehler M43 PBL system

Title: Testing of .357 Magnum Hollow Point Bullets in Water
Author Keywords: PURPOSE: To test the performance of current .357 Magnum JHP ammunition. METHOD: Firing vertically downward into a water tank from which bullets were recovered. RESULTS: The expansion of 9 of the 11 bullets tested was relatively adequate and uniform CONCLUSION: Expansion of .357 Magnum bullets appears to have improved in the past decade.  In 1988, Fackler reported testing of four ! 58 grain .357 Magnum soft point bullets, made by major bullet manufacturers, shooting them into 1 0% ordnance gelatin shot at a block temperature of 4° C. Only one of these bullets expanded adequately and consistently. He published photographs of the recovered bullets and decried the poor bullet performance. 1 The purpose of this paper is to test the expansion adequacy and consistently of a large group of expanding .357 Magnum bullets.

Title: 9mm Flobert Bullet
Authors with affiliations: A Case Report By Lakdar Attar and Andre Desmarais, Laboratoire de Police Scientifique de Lyon, France
Author Keywords: Recently, a 9 mm Flobert lead bullet and a carbine chambered in this calibre were submitted for examination. The question of the judge was: did this gun shoot this bullet? After a macroscopic examination of this bullet, we were in a position to match it to the test bullets. To validate this opinion, the possibility to identify bullets fired in other unrifled bores was checked.
Index Keywords: 9mm Flobert, bullet, match, unrifled bores

Title: Balloting Bullets: Exterior and Wound Ballistics of Balloted Bullets Physical Characteristics of Balloted Bullets and Associated Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: Lucien C. Haag, Forensic Science Services, Carefree, AZ
Author Keywords: A number of mismatched cartridges can be readily loaded and fired in certain firearms without difficulty. Examples include .380 Automatic ammunition in 9mm Makarovs, 9mm Luger in 40 S&W pistols and .270 Winchester in 30-'06 rifles. The bullets ballot down the bore acquiring intermittent rifling marks and emerge with reduced muzzle velocities. Most of these bullets are not spin-stabilized and tumble in flight. As a consequence they have very poor exterior ballistic properties. In the case of 9mm bullets from a .40 S&W pistol, ballistic coefficients are on the order of 0.025 to 0.030 compared to values of .14 to .20 for spin-stabilized 9mm bullets weighing 115 grains to 147 grains. Bullet holes in clothing and entry wounds produced by these balloted bullets will frquently reflect their tumbling nature followed by relatively shallow bullet penetration depths in tissue due to yawed impacts and reduced impact velocity. The necks of the fired cartridge cases will expand to fit the chamber often without splitting. Nine-millimter Luger cartridges must be manually extracted and ejected from a .40 S&W pistol whereas .380 Automatic cartridges will cycle the action of a 9mm Makarov.
Index Keywords: ballot, balloting bullets, rifling impressions, internal ballistics, exterior ballistics, wound ballistics, ballistic coefficient, Yuma Proving Grounds, Doppler radar

Author Keywords: Reported is the case of a man killed by a neighbor with a shotgun loaded with a unusual ammunition. The cartridge contained several shots chained together by metallic wires. Such ammunition has been used for hunting purposes but is now banned, so it can be handmade only. The joined pellets produce a wound with features that are different from those of a wound made by a regular load of pellets. Several interpretive problems are caused by the unknown number of pellets contained in the shell and the effects of the wire holding the shot together.

Authors: Shoshani E., Argaman U., Giverts P.
Title: Alteration of .38 Special Ammunition to .38 Smith & Wesson Ammunition
Authors with affiliations: Ezra Shoshani, B.Sc. (Eng.); Uri Argaman, M.B.A., B.Sc. (Eng.); Pavel Giverts, M.Sc. (Eng.), Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel Police National Headquarters, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Sixteen rounds of live ammunition were seized from a suspect. The ammunition was unique in that its outside dimensions appeared to be of .38 S&W caliber, while the head stamps were 'WINCHESTER .38 SPL". These discrepancies posed questions concerning the origin of the ammunition. These cartridges were found to be originally .38 Special caliber, however, the cases were trimmed to the approximate length of .38 Smith & Wesson caliber casings, and reloaded with the original .38 Special bullets. This ammunition was found to have a muzzle velocity approximately 30% higher than Winchester .38 Smith & Wesson caliber ammunition from the firearms laboratory reference collection

Authors: Waghmare N.P., Manna A., Rao M.S., Sen P.K.
Title: Statistical analysis of impact parameters of soft nose bullet fired on windowpane

Author Keywords: Proper collection of glass evidence from crime spot is very important for its latter probative values. Glass evidence when properly collected and analyzed becomes a powerful witness and it can speak truth long after the crime. In criminal investigation glass evidence can tell what had happened and when it had happened. In the present study, a statistical regression analysis relationship between thickness of windowpane used as targets by soft nose bullet using .315″/8mm caliber sporting gun made in ordnance factory, India and various associated impact parameters were investigated. The relationship is found to be reasonably linear. The ballistics performance of windowpane has been found to correlate with the shear strength behavior above the elastic limit. © 2003 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: De Kinder J., Lory S., Van Laere W., Demuynck E.
Title: The deviation of bullets passing through window panes
Affiliations: Nationaal Instituut voor Criminalistiek en Criminologie (NICC/INCC), Ministerie van Justitie, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Kinder, J., Nationaal Instituut voor Criminalistiek en Criminologie (NICC/INCC), Ministerie van Justitie, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium; Lory, S., Nationaal Instituut voor Criminalistiek en Criminologie (NICC/INCC), Ministerie van Justitie, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium; Van Laere, W., Nationaal Instituut voor Criminalistiek en Criminologie (NICC/INCC), Ministerie van Justitie, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium; Demuynck, E., Nationaal Instituut voor Criminalistiek en Criminologie (NICC/INCC), Ministerie van Justitie, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium
Author Keywords: The deviation of bullets passing through window pane glass of a thickness of 6mm was investigated for varying angles of incidence. Projectiles of calibre 0.22 and 0.38 (wadcutter) were used. The 0.22 bullets break into multiple pieces, resulting in a large distribution of exit angles. An increasing deviation of 0.38 wadcutter projectiles was seen for increasing angles of incidence. For incident angles larger than 35°, an unexpected ricochet was noticed. This phenomenon is of importance when examining crime scenes. A number of parameters which have to be taken into account for further experiments is suggested. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Bullet trajectory reconstruction; Glass; Ricochet; Terminal ballistics

Title: Bullet Deflection Due to Angled Intervening Materials
Authors with affiliations: Dale Theiling, Honors Intern, Firearms-Toolmarks Unit, Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, D.C.
Author Keywords: In many crime scene investigations, bullet trajectory evaluations are assumed to be a direct line-of-flight situation. However, logic would imply that intervening materials that present a bullet with an angled surface should deflect the bullet's path. Experiments were run to test the deflection effects of seve ral common materials (drywall, plywood, and sheet metal) with different caliber cartridges (9mm and .40 caliber) when impacted at various angles. The results provide interesting and worthwhile conclusions, and may necessitate a change in trajectory evaluations under certain circumstances.
Index Keywords: bullet deflection, bullet trajectory, drywall, plywood, sheet metal

Title: Determination of chemical life of combustible cartridge cases
Affiliations: High Energy Materials Research Laboratory, Pune, 411 021, India
Authors with affiliations: Peshave, J.R., High Energy Materials Research Laboratory, Pune, 411 021, India; Singh, H., High Energy Materials Research Laboratory, Pune, 411 021, India
Author Keywords: Determination of the stability and prediction of the chemical life of Combustible Cartridge Cases (CCCs) which are extensively used in the high calibre tank gun ammunition is one of the major requirement for manufacturer. The results obtained by carrying out accelerated aging of CCC samples at elevated temperatures are discussed in this paper. The plot of residual stabilizer content (%) versus time (days) has been used in the Woolwich formula and Berthelot's equation to extrapolate the life at normal storage temperature, (30°C). Also chemical life was determined by subjecting CCC sample to standard Woolwich stability test. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Compositional variation in bullet lead manufacture
Affiliations: Forensic Science Research Unit, FBI Laboratory, FBI Academy, Quantico, VA, United States; Chemistry Unit, FBI Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koons, R.D., Forensic Science Research Unit, FBI Laboratory, FBI Academy, Quantico, VA, United States; Grant, D.M., Chemistry Unit, FBI Laboratory, Washington, DC, United States
Author Keywords: The concentrations of antimony, copper, tin, arsenic, silver, bismuth, and cadmium in lead alloys produced by two smelters and one ammunition manufacturer were determined using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry. These element concentrations were used to measure the variations in composition of lead products that result from various processes involved in the manufacture of lead projectiles. In general, when a pot containing molten lead is used to cast a number of objects, these objects are similar, although not necessarily analytically indistinguishable in their elemental compositions. In each subsequent step in the processing of lead at the smelter and at the ammunition manufacturer, the size of an individual homogeneous melt of lead decreases as more distinct compositions are formed as a result of remelting and mixing of sources, including lead scrap. The ammunition manufacturer in this study produced at least 10 compositionally distinguishable groups of bullet wire in a 19.7-h period. The largest group could potentially be used to produce a maximum of 1.3 million compositionally indistinguishable 40 grain bullets.
Index Keywords: Bullet; Criminalistics; Elemental analysis; Forensic science; ICP-AES; Lead analysis; Trace evidence

Authors: Randich E., Duerfeldt W., McLendon W., Tobin W.
Title: A metallurgical review of the interpretation of bullet lead compositional analysis
Affiliations: FMI, 927 Creekside Place, Manteca, CA 95336, United States; Gopher Resource Corporation, 3385 South Hwy. 149, Eagan, MN 55121, United States; Sanders Lead Co. Inc., P.O. Drawer 707, Troy, AL 36081, United States; 6009 Noranda Drive, Mineral, VA 23117-9647, United States
Authors with affiliations: Randich, E., FMI, 927 Creekside Place, Manteca, CA 95336, United States; Duerfeldt, W., Gopher Resource Corporation, 3385 South Hwy. 149, Eagan, MN 55121, United States; McLendon, W., Sanders Lead Co. Inc., P.O. Drawer 707, Troy, AL 36081, United States; Tobin, W., 6009 Noranda Drive, Mineral, VA 23117-9647, United States
Author Keywords: Comparison of the minor and trace element compositions of bullet lead alloys has been used by some forensic examiners to make definitive positive associations between bullets or lead fragments at a crime scene and samples of bullets linked to a suspect(s). Such conclusions have been based on the elemental analysis of isolated groups of bullets with no consideration of the metallurgical processes involved in the production and refining of the bullet lead alloys. An understanding of the metallurgy of lead refining reveals that the elements quantified in the forensic analysis are carefully controlled in the refining process and that there are logical reasons why some elements are more discriminatory than others. Data for lead alloys supplied to two major ammunition manufacturers confirm that multiple indistinguishable shipments of lead alloys from secondary lead refiners to the ammunition manufacturers are made each year and over a period of many years. The data also demonstrate that distinguishable compositions can come from the same melt or "source" of lead alloy. These results clearly indicate that bullets with indistinguishable compositions could have come from different lead "sources" produced in the same or different years. Furthermore, the observation that two bullets have a distinguishable composition does not necessarily mean that they came from a different "source". Our results show that the forensic examiner using a method of bullet lead alloy elemental analysis, which quantifies up to six elements is restricted to concluding only that indistinguishable bullets might have come from the same "source," not that they did come from the same "source". In addition, it is quite possible that multiple bullets with similar but distinguishable compositions could have come from the same "source". The authors therefore feel that there is no scientific validity to any conclusions more positive than attributing the possible association as to molten source among bullets from different samples. An understanding of the metallurgical principles operative in the melting/casting process as well as the data acquired for this study, indicate that any forensic conclusions which associate unknown bullets with the "same source", and/or "same box" should fail most or all Daubert criteria. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Bullet; Elemental analysis; Forensic science; Lead; Metallurgy
Correspondence Address: alloy; lead; article; bullet; chemical composition; forensic identification; metallurgy; priority journal; quantitative analysis; validation process

Authors: Çakir I., Çetin G., Uner H.B., Albek E.
Title: Shot range estimation based on pellet distribution in shots with a pump-action shotgun
Affiliations: Department of Forensic Medicine, Cerrahpasa Faculty of Medicine, Instanbul University, Istanbul, Turkey; Institute of Forensic Sciences, Instanbul University, Istanbul, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Çakir, I.; Çetin, G., Department of Forensic Medicine, Cerrahpasa Faculty of Medicine, Instanbul University, Istanbul, Turkey; Uner, H.B., Institute of Forensic Sciences, Instanbul University, Istanbul, Turkey; Albek, E., Department of Forensic Medicine, Cerrahpasa Faculty of Medicine, Instanbul University, Istanbul, Turkey
Author Keywords: In the present study, shots from different ranges were fired using a non-choked pump-action shotgun (Hugsan) of calibre 12 with a bore length of 52cm and pellets of various sizes. The aim of the study is range estimation from the distribution of pellets. Using pellets of 2, 3.5, 5 and 8mm size, 5 shots were fired from: 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25ms. The maximum distance between the pellets in vertical and horizontal direction was measured. Statistical evaluation of the data revealed a highly significant correlation for each pellet type; the constant values a and b were calculated to be used in the linear regression equation y=a+bx. As a conclusion, the linear regression equation as well as table data may allow range determination within acceptable ranges of error for the same barrel length and diameter for the same cartridge type. Under identical conditions they may also provide information for pellets of comparable size. © 2003 Published by Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Distribution pattern; Pellets; Pump-action shotgun; Range estimation

Title: Average Pellet-to-Pellet Distance for Estimating Range-of-Fire in Cases Involving Partial Pellet Patterns

Author Keywords: An alternate method for estimating range-of-fire for partial pellet patterns is presented. The average separation distance between neighboring pellet impact sites is measured for a number of test shots at known ranges and a graph of average pellet-to-pellet distance vs. range prepared. Title: Ballistic fingerprinting databases
Source title: Science and Justice - Journal of the Forensic Science Society
Affiliations: Nationaal Inst. V. Criminalistiek, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Kinder, J., Nationaal Inst. V. Criminalistiek, Vilvoordsesteenweg 98-100, B-1120 Brussels, Belgium
Author Keywords: This article discusses a number of questions regarding the setting up of ballistic fingerprinting databases, consisting of ammunition components fired by all the firearms held in legal possession. These questions can be classified into three categories - the efficiency of the database, forensic issues, and practical issues to be dealt with. The current New York State legislation is used as an illustration of the choices to be made when setting up a ballistic fingerprinting database. Three important arguments are formulated against the installation of a ballistic fingerprinting database.

Title: Content based information retrieval in forensic image databases
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 GD Rijswijk, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Geradts, Z., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 GD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Bijhold, J., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 GD Rijswijk, Netherlands
Author Keywords: This paper gives an overview of the various available image databases and ways of searching these databases on image contents. The developments in research groups of searching in image databases is evaluated and compared with the forensic databases that exist. Forensic image databases of fingerprints, faces, shoeprints, handwriting, cartridge cases, drugs tablets, and tool marks are described. The developments in these fields appear to be valuable for forensic databases, especially that of the framework in MPEG-7, where the searching in image databases is standardized. In the future, the combination of the databases (also DNA-databases) and possibilities to combine these can result in stronger forensic evidence.

Title: IBIS and the 5.56 NATO Cartridge Case Fired from an M-16
Authors with affiliations: By: P. Giverts and E. Springer, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS) Israel National Police
Author Keywords: Over the past two years, there has been a tremendous rise in terrorism experienced throughout Israel. One of the main weapons used in these terror -related incidents has been the M-16 assault rifle. In general, the marks on cartridge cases used for IBIS system comparison purposes include those left by the firing pin, breech face and ejector. However, there are firearms whose toolmarks are of a quality and shape that do not allow for IBIS generated results' such as the M-16, and other assault rifles, whose firing pin and breech face markings are weak and who leave no regular ejector mark (although there is an ejector cut-out mark). It was therefore decided to investigate the feasability of using a better mark, such as the extractor mark, instead of the ejector cut-out mark. In the first stage of this work, data was collected from existing X-file cartridge cases to see how many had the ejector cut-out mark as opposed to the extractor mark. A statistical survey was performed as to see how often these marks appear when looking at a variety of ammunition types fired from many M-16's. Because the IBIS optics could not accommodate the full cut-out mark, the protocol used in our laboratory was to acquire either the top portion or the bottom portion (sub-areas). Here too, it was decided to collect data regarding these two areas. Two hundred and thirty cartridge cases fired from fifty-six weapons were examined. These cartridges were taken from the x-file of real cases. After a preliminary examination, three sub-areas from the ejector cut-out mark and two sub-areas from the extractor mark were chosen for closer examination. In the next stage, the present IBIS system's capability of dealing with the targeted marks was examined. M-16's from the lab's collection were fired and the cartridge cases were collected and acquired into the system. Five areas from each cartridge case were acquired; the three sub-areas of the ejector cut-out mark and the two sub-areas of the extractor mark. The goal of this work was to examine the possibility of improving the IBIS' ability to deal with cartridge case comparisons from firearms such as the M-16 or other assault rifles such as the Galil, Kalachnikov, M-14, etc. The extractor mark in the M-16 was found to be present in most (91%) of the cartridge cases examined and proved to be very useful for correlation purposes. The chamber lug marks also seem to be important for use in comparison work. With some changes and modifications, the IBIS could be adapted to use protocols for aquiring these marks. These marks are more useful for comparison purposes and could either replace or be used in addition to the firing pin and breech face mark.
Index Keywords: IBIS, 5.56 NATO, M-16, ejector, extractor, firing pin, breechface

Authors: Geradts Z.J., Bijhold J., Hermsen R., Murtagh F.
Title: Image matching algorithms for breech face marks and firing pins in a database of spent cartridge cases of firearms
Affiliations: Department Digital Technology, Netherlands Forensic Institute, Ministry of Justice, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 CD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Department of Physics, Netherlands Forensic Institute, Ministry of Justice, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 CD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Queen's University of Belfast, Northern Ireland, Belfast BT7 1NN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Geradts, Z.J., Department Digital Technology, Netherlands Forensic Institute, Ministry of Justice, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 CD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Bijhold, J., Department Digital Technology, Netherlands Forensic Institute, Ministry of Justice, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 CD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Hermsen, R., Department of Physics, Netherlands Forensic Institute, Ministry of Justice, Volmerlaan 17, 2288 CD Rijswijk, Netherlands; Murtagh, F., Queen's University of Belfast, Northern Ireland, Belfast BT7 1NN, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: On the market several systems exist for collecting spent ammunition data for forensic investigation. These databases store images of cartridge cases and the marks on them. Image matching is used to create hit lists that show which marks on a cartridge case are most similar to another cartridge case. The research in this paper is focused on the different methods of feature selection and pattern recognition that can be used for optimizing the results of image matching.The images are acquired by side light images for the breech face marks and by ring light for the firing pin impression. For these images a standard way of digitizing the images used. For the side light images and ring light images this means that the user has to position the cartridge case in the same position according to a protocol. The positioning is important for the sidelight, since the image that is obtained of a striation mark depends heavily on the angle of incidence of the light. In practice, it appears that the user positions the cartridge case with ±10° accuracy.We tested our algorithms using 49 cartridge cases of 19 different firearms, where the examiner determined that they were shot with the same firearm. For testing, these images were mixed with a database consisting of approximately 4900 images that were available from the Drugfire database of different calibers.In cases where the registration and the light conditions among those matching pairs was good, a simple computation of the standard deviation of the subtracted gray levels, delivered the best-matched images. For images that were rotated and shifted, we have implemented a 'brute force' way of registration. The images are translated and rotated until the minimum of the standard deviation of the difference is found. This method did not result in all relevant matches in the top position. This is caused by the effect that shadows and highlights are compared in intensity. Since the angle of incidence of the light will give a different intensity profile, this method is not optimal.For this reason a preprocessing of the images was required. It appeared that the third scale of the 'à trous' wavelet transform gives the best results in combination with brute force. Matching the contents of the images is less sensitive to the variation of the lighting.The problem with the brute force method is however that the time for calculation for 49 cartridge cases to compare between them, takes over 1 month of computing time on a Pentium II-computer with 333MHz. For this reason a faster approach is implemented: correlation in log polar coordinates. This gave similar results as the brute force calculation, however it was computed in 24h for a complete database with 4900 images.A fast pre-selection method based on signatures is carried out that is based on the Kanade Lucas Tomasi (KLT) equation. The positions of the points computed with this method are compared. In this way, 11 of the 49 images were in the top position in combination with the third scale of the à trous equation. It depends however on the light conditions and the prominence of the marks if correct matches are found in the top ranked position. All images were retrieved in the top 5% of the database. This method takes only a few minutes for the complete database if, and can be optimized for comparison in seconds if the location of points are stored in files.For further improvement, it is useful to have the refinement in which the user selects the areas that are relevant on the cartridge case for their marks. This is necessary if this cartridge case is damaged and other marks that are not from the firearm appear on it. Copyright © 2001 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Cartridge case; Firearms; Forensic science; Image database; Image matching; Pattern recognition; Wavelets

Author Keywords: This report presents a new way, which the authors believe is the optimal way, of achieving proper candidate ranking by calculating the Phase score as an Average Phase score, using the existing LEA-to-LEA (LEA-Land Engraved Area) correlation scores received from the Signature Analysis Station (SAS), in the IBIS (Integrated Ballistics Identification System). This average Phase scoring can help re-order the Max phase and Peak Phase correlation results lists; thus the best potential candidate bullets that have already been found in the system will be ranked in higher positions within the two lists.

Title: Effects of Ultrasonic Cleaning of Bullets on IBIS Correlation Scores: A Preliminary Report
Authors with affiliations: Mitch Rector, Firearms Examiner, Birmingham Police Department, Birmingham, Alabama
Author Keywords: Bullets are often submitted for examination bearing various forms of debris on their surface. One method encountered to remove this debris is the use of an ultrasonic cleaner. The dynamic nature of the ultrasonic cleaning pprocess raises the question as to what effect the process has on the surface and ultimately the information contained there and its effect on an identification. Simple experiments were conducted using jacketed and lead bullets subjected to an ultrasonic cleaner for specified intervals. This preliminary study suggests that ultrasonic cleaning does have an effect on IBIS correlation scores; the effect being markedly different between bare lead and copper jacketed bullets.
Index Keywords: bullet correlation, IBIS scores, ultrasonic cleaning

Title: Development of a 3D-based automated firearms evidence comparison system
Affiliations: Dept. of Electro-mechanical Systems, Intelligent Automation, Inc., 7519 Standish Place, Rockville, MD 20855, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bachrach, B., Dept. of Electro-mechanical Systems, Intelligent Automation, Inc., 7519 Standish Place, Rockville, MD 20855, United States
Author Keywords: Since the early 1990's, the idea of automated systems for the comparison of microscopic firearms evidence has received considerable attention. The main objective of such systems is to enable the analysis of large amounts of evidence, therefore, transforming the comparison of firearms evidence from an evidence verification tool into a crime-fighting tool. Two such systems have been widely used in United States forensic laboratories; namely, the Integrated Ballistics Identification System (IBIS) (1) and DRUGFIRE (2). Both IBIS and DRUGFIRE have in common the fact that their characterization of a specimen is based on a two-dimensional (2D) representation of the specimen's surface. Although these systems have provided satisfactory results in the identification of cartridge cases, their performance in the identification of bullets has not yet met firearms examiner's expectations. This project was motivated by the premise that a better characterizations of the bullet's surface should translate into better performance of automated identification systems. A three-dimensional (3D) characterization of the bullet's surface is proposed as an alternative to a 2D characterization. This paper discusses the development and preliminary results obtained with SCICLOPS™, an automated microscopic comparison system based on the use of a 3D characterization of a bullet's surface.
Index Keywords: 3D forensic imaging; Automated comparison of microscopic firearms evidence; Firearms identification; Forensic science
Correspondence Address: article; automation; ballistics; bullet; comparative study; device; firearm; priority journal; surface property; United States

Title: Possibility of Bullet Identification Using 3D Data
Source title: Japanese Journal of Science and Technology for Identification
Author Keywords: This study focuses on identification of bullets with three-dimensional data of landmark impressions. Generally, forensic scientists identify bullets by optical tools. For example, a comparison microscope, a CCD camera and photographs etc. Although these approaches are very essential and effective, the appearance of a striation depends on an illumination system in these methods. Therefore, there might remain some problems in the database that consist of only photometric data. On the other hand, 3D data of impressions on fired bullets are expected to possess generality and objectivity for forensic identification because the database that consists of geometric data is perfectly independent of any illumination. In this study, I used a confocal microscope as a 3D measurement device. I examined two jacketed bullets fired from a 0.25 caliber gun and six jacketed bullets fired from three 0.32 caliber guns. Each bullet had six landmark impressions, and there were twenty-four pairs of landmark impressions to be compared. The texture of a landmark impression is uniform along the direction of the scratch. It is expected that 3D profile is also uniform along the direction, so averaging 3D data along the direction can reduce an influence of measurement error. The averaged profile, shown as a 2D curve, fills the role of a characteristic profile. The 2D comparison of these profiles serves as bullet identification. Minute variations that form vivid striation were not shown clearly because of the averaging procedure. However, the comparisons of 24 pairs made it clear that global shapes of two profiles from the same origin coincide. Therefore, a sectional shape of a landmark impression would be a useful method for bullet identification when the bullet is not deformed and 3D shape of an impression is a little unique.
Index Keywords: 3D profile comparison; bullet identification; confocal optics

Authors: Thali M.J., Braun M., Brueschweiler W., Dirnhofer R.
Title: 'Morphological imprint': Determination of the injury-causing weapon from the wound morphology using forensic 3D/CAD-supported photogrammetry
Affiliations: Institute of Forensic Medicine, University of Berne, Buehlstrasse 20, CH-3012 Berne, Switzerland; Scientific Forensic Service, Zurich City Police, CH-8004 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Thali, M.J., Institute of Forensic Medicine, University of Berne, Buehlstrasse 20, CH-3012 Berne, Switzerland; Braun, M., Scientific Forensic Service, Zurich City Police, CH-8004 Zurich, Switzerland; Brueschweiler, W., Scientific Forensic Service, Zurich City Police, CH-8004 Zurich, Switzerland; Dirnhofer, R., Institute of Forensic Medicine, University of Berne, Buehlstrasse 20, CH-3012 Berne, Switzerland
Author Keywords: Forensic three-dimensional/computer aided design (CAD)-supported photogrammetry (FPHG) plays an important role in the field of the documentation of forensic relevant injuries; particularly so when a detailed, 3D reconstruction is necessary. This is demonstrated in the case of a patterned blunt injury to the face of a victim, which injury was subsequently proven by FPHG to have been caused by a blow from the muzzle of a soft air gun. The objects to be evaluated had to be series photographed in order to be evaluated virtually on the computer. These photo series were then analyzed with the RolleiMetric system. This system measures and calculates the spatial location of distinctive points on the objects' surfaces, and creates 3D data models of the objects. In a 3D/CAD program, the "virtual 3D model of the injury" is then compared against the "virtual 3D model of the possible injury-causing instrument". The validation of FPHG, as shown by the 3D match between certain characteristics of the muzzle form and the facial injury, demonstrates how this 3D method can be used for patterned wound documentation and analysis. © 2003 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: 3D/CAD; Forensic photogrammetry; Forensic wound documentation; Morphological imprint; Patterned injuries; Reconstruction
Correspondence Address: adult; article; blunt trauma; calculation; case report; computer program; device; face injury; female; forensic medicine; gunshot injury; human; medical documentation; photography; priority journal; victim

Authors: Subke J., Haase S., Wehner H.D., Wehner F.
Title: Computer Aided Shot Reconstructions by Means of Individualised Animated Three-Dimensional Victim Models
Author Keywords: In cases of lethal firearm injuries with indefinite indications concerning self-versus third-party infliction a computer enhanced reconstruction with the aim of an anatomical feasibility study can provide significant clues concerning the course of the traumatic event. To this end an exact three-dimensional geometrical model of the victim including all relevant anatomical data as well as the careful documentation of the injuries and a three-dimensional model of the characteristic outlines of the weapon true to scale is generated with the help of an animation program (POSER Version 4, Meta Creation, Egisys AG). With this animated digital three-dimensional model of the victim and the weapon a series of simulation sequences is created by variation of the body positions and the grasp of the weapon. Anatomically impossible positions in view of the physical characteristics of the victim and the site and direction of the bullet path are automatically excluded from the reconstruction. An exact match of the simulation sequence and the real injuries is a statement for a possible self-infliction of the gunshot wound.
Index Keywords: Shot reconstruction; Individual three-dimensional animated victim model; Three-dimensional injury documentation; Streifenlichttopometrie (SLT)

Title: Firearm and toolmark identification criteria: A review of the literature, part II
Affiliations: ATF Forensic Science Laboratory, San Francisco, CA, United States; Bur. of Alcohol, Tobacco,/Firearms, San Francisco Laboratory Center, 355 North Wiget Lane, Walnut Creek, CA 94598, United States

Author Keywords: An update to a previously published review of articles pertaining to firearm and toolmark identification criteria is presented. In this update, 22 additional articles were reviewed, including works of a general nature, studies critically assessing the theory of consecutive matching striations, empirical studies involving various firearm components, toolmark studies, as well as articles discussing the utility of statistics in the firearms and toolmark identification discipline. These articles have been reviewed in a format to permit others to learn what has been published in the field in an effort to educate interested parties. Further, a discussion of the importance of articulation and communication within the discipline is presented.

Title: Analysis of the Essential Aspects of Striated Tool Mark Examinations and the Methods for Identification
Authors with affiliations: Kristen A. Tomasetti, Firearms/Toolmark Examiner, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, Rockville, MD
Author Keywords: There are many aspects that help ensure firearms and toolmark examinations are reliably conducted and yield valid conclusions, including the availability of specialized tools, the examiner's training and experience, established laboratory protocols and other formal guidelines. It is the examiner's responsibility to analyze evidence and determine if a positive identification exists. There are two similar methods for establishing an identification: traditional pattern recognition and pattern recognition with consecutive matching striations (CMS) utilizing the conservative numerical criteria. All examiners use the traditional pattern recognition method, which usually generates reliable and valid results when applied properly. Because the possibility of making a misidentificaton still exists, some examiners feel there is a need to utilize a more objective method. Whether an examiner employs the traditional pattern recognition method or CMS with the conservative criteria for identification, it is essential for them to be able to communicate the reliability of their examination methods and conclusions clearly and convincingly in a courtroom.
Index Keywords: confidence level, conservative criteria, consecutive matching striations (CMS)

Title: A case of "boomerang" bullet ricochet
Affiliations: Institute of Legal Medicine, University of Münster, Von-Esmarch-Strasse 62, 48149 Münster, Germany; Department of Surgery, University of Münster, Waldeyerstrasse 1, 48129 Münster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Karger, B., Institute of Legal Medicine, University of Münster, Von-Esmarch-Strasse 62, 48149 Münster, Germany; Joosten, U., Department of Surgery, University of Münster, Waldeyerstrasse 1, 48129 Münster, Germany
Author Keywords: A .375 Holland & Holland Magnum Winchester Fail Safe bullet was fired against a steel plate. The big-game hunting bullet (17.4 g, approx. 810 m/s) has a solid copper-alloy hollow point design including a lead core limited to the rear portion. The range of firing was 20 m and the angle of impact was 90°. A large fragment (10.9 g) consisting of the main part of the copper portion was deformed in a peculiar manner similar to a tube or ring and wounded the left hand of the person shooting. The unique fragment trajectory strictly against the line of fire and the velocity sufficient to shatter bone after a distance of 20 m can be explained by an extraordinary deformation mechanism. Unlike in tissue, the high resistance of the steel plate caused the lead core in the rear of the bullet to move forward perforating the central copper barrier behind the hollow point cavity. Thus, the peculiar fragment was created. The subsequent backwards acceleration of the ring-like fragment was probably caused by the partly elastic impact of the copper-alloy portion against the hard steel plate. Due to the perpendicular impact resulting in a centric and symmetrical deformation, the fragment moved in a direction exactly backwards along the original line of fire.
Index Keywords: Bullet fragment; Fragment injury; Gunshot wound; Ricochet
Correspondence Address: alloy; copper; acceleration; article; bullet; case report; clinical feature; gunshot injury; human; pain assessment; priority journal; safety; velocity; Hand Injuries; Humans; Wounds, Gunshot

Authors: Ismach R.B., Reza A., Ary R., Sampson T.R., Bartolomeos K., Kellermann A.L.
Title: Unintended shootings in a large metropolitan area: An incident-based analysis
Affiliations: Center for Injury Control, Rollins School of Public Health of Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Department of Emergency Medicine, School of Medicine, Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ismach, R.B., Center for Injury Control, Rollins School of Public Health of Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Reza, A., Department of Emergency Medicine, School of Medicine, Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Ary, R., Department of Emergency Medicine, School of Medicine, Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Sampson, T.R., Center for Injury Control, Rollins School of Public Health of Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Bartolomeos, K., Center for Injury Control, Rollins School of Public Health of Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States; Kellermann, A.L., Center for Injury Control, Rollins School of Public Health of Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States, Department of Emergency Medicine, School of Medicine, Emory University, Atlanta, GA, United States
Author Keywords: Study objective: We determine the proportion of unintended shootings that might be prevented by promoting safe storage, safe handling, and/or safer firearm designs. Methods: A regional firearm injury surveillance system was used to identify fatal and nonfatal unintentional shootings in a 5-county metropolitan area. Case reports were reviewed, and the causes of each shooting were independently classified by 4 members of the research team. A consensus conference was held to resolve disagreements. Results: Between May 1, 1996, and June 30, 2000, 216 cases of unintentional firearm injury were identified, 3.8% of the shootings documented during the study period. Six (2.8%) were fatal. The majority of victims were between 15 and 34 years of age. One fourth (54) of the shootings involved victims younger than 18 years. Handguns were involved in 87% of the incidents. Enough information was available to characterize the incident in 122 (57%) cases. All but 6 fell into 1 or more of 3 broad categories of causation: child access (14%), mishandling (74%), and/or deficiencies in firearm design (32%). Conclusion: Many unintentional shootings could be prevented by promoting safe storage of guns in the home, promoting safe handling of firearms, and requiring that all new handguns incorporate basic safety features.
