Authors: Wevers G., Neel M.T., Buckleton J.
Title: A Comprehensive Statistical Analysis of Striated Toolmark Examinations Part 2: Comparing Known Matches and Known Non-Matches using Likelihood Ratios
Authors with affiliations: Gerhard Wevers, Michael Neel and John Buckleton
Author Keywords: A potential model for increasing the objectivity in the interpretation of toolmarks is explored using consecutively matching striae (CMS) and Bayesian inference. Given the nature of the data, standard statistical thinking suggests that Bayesian inference is likely to be the most powerful method of interpretation. The unavoidable paucity of data for high CMS runs for the known non-match condition is handled using a small advance in modelling. The resulting likelihood ratios show some, but incomplete separation between the known match and known non-match conditions. Although promising, the resulting incomplete separation between known match and known non-match is thought to represent limitations of the CMS summary of the complete pattern and limitations of the modelling used.
Index Keywords: Bayesian inference, CMS, Criteria, Firearms, Toolmarks

Authors: Mikko D., Miller J., Flater J.
Title: Reproducibility of Toolmarks on 20,000 Bullets fired through an M240 Machine Gun Barrel
Authors with affiliations: Don Mikko, Jerry Miller and Jason Flater, United States Army Criminal Investigation Laboratory (USACIL), 4930 N 31st Street, Forest Park, GA 30297, USA
Author Keywords: This article discusses the reproducibility of toolmarks on 7.62mm high velocity bullets fired through a single M240 machine gun barrel. Over the years, there have been several research studies and published articles pertaining to consecutively manufactured rifled barrels and the ability to microscopically identify bullets as having been fired through the same barrel of a firearm; however, to the knowledge of the authors, there has not been any in-depth microscopic study pertaining to 20,000 bullets being fired through a single rifled barrel and subsequently identified to that particular barrel. Based on the recent findings as stated in the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) Report, this article should provide credible evidence in regards to the reproducibility and uniqueness of striations on the bearing surfaces of fired bullets.
Index Keywords: M240 Machine gun, 7.62x51mm NATO cartridge, reproducibility, bullets

Title: IBIS Correlation Results of Cartridge Cases Collected Over the Course of 500 Firings from a Glock Pistol
Authors with affiliations: Terrence L. Grom, Jr., University of Illinois at Chicago, Forensic Science Masters Program, Chicago, Illinois William E. Demuth, II, Illinois State Police Forensic Science Center at Chicago, Chicago, Illinois
Author Keywords: This study examines the capability of the IBIS system to find known matching fired cartridge cases that have been produced after the moderate use of a GlockTM firearm. A total of 500 cartridges were fired from a GlockTM pistol. The individual characteristics of the breech face and firing pin persisted throughout the firings, and IBIS was able to properly correlate the known match within the top twenty results for each cartridge case entered.
Index Keywords: BrassTRAX-3D, Breech face, Consecutively fired cartridge case, Correlation, Firing pin, Firing pin aperture shear marks, Glock, IBIS, Longevity of toolmarks, Individual characteristics

Title: The Persistence of Chamber Marks from Two Semiautomatic Pistols on Over 1,440 Sequentially-Fired Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: April Stowe, Southwestern Institute of Forensic Sciences, Dallas, Texas
Author Keywords: A Browning Hi-Power semiautomatic pistol and a Hi-Point model C semiautomatic pistol were test fired a total of 1,440 times each, and their chamber marks were examined. Ammunition used included cartridges with cases made of aluminum, brass, and nickel-plated brass. Microscopic comparison of the chamber marks revealed that they were reproducible and identifiable up to 960 firings and that the metallic composition of the cartridge case does affect the reproducibility of the chamber marks.
Index Keywords: Browning Hi-Power, cartridge cases, casting, chamber marks, fire-formed marks, Hi-Point model C, impressed marks, individual characteristics, longevity, obturation marks, persistence of marks, reproducibility, static marks, striated marks

Title: An Emperical and Validation Study of Breechface Marks on .380 ACP Caliber Cartridge Cases Fired from Ten Consecutively Finished Hi-Point Model C9 Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Dawn LaPorte, Pasadena Police Department Regional Crime Laboratory, Pasadena, Texas
Author Keywords: An empirical study was conducted using ten (10) consecutively finished Hi-Point model C9 slides and one frame acquired from the Hi-Point Manufacturing Company in Mansfield, Ohio. The ten (10) slides were mounted on the frame and test fired to obtain cartridge cases for comparison. The test fired cartridge cases were microscopically examined, evaluated and compared for class and individual characteristics that resulted from the manufacturing process. Prominent striations were evident on each test-fired cartridge case. These resulted from sanding of the breech face. The variations that occur during the manufacturing process of sanding result in unique, identifiable, individual breech face marks devoid of subclass influence. A limited validation study was conducted after the empirical study. Correct associations were made during this limited study.
Index Keywords: Consecutive Breech Face Marks; Consecutively finished Hi-Point breech face(s); Empirical; Individual characteristics; Sanding; Validation

Title: An Emperial Study to Evaluate the Repeatability and Uniqueness of Striations/Impressions Imparted on Consecutively Manufactured Glock EBIS Gun barrels
Authors with affiliations: Thomas G. Fadul Jr., Ph.D., Laboratory Manager, Miami-Dade Police Department
Author Keywords: The inability to identify fired bullets to individual Glock pistols resulted in an in-depth study of Glock+s polygonal rifled barrels, which resulted in the manufacturing of the Miami Barrel. The Miami Barrel was designed with the intent to give the barrel a unique signature. Glock has marketed the Miami Barrel as the Enhanced Bullet Identification System (EBIS). These barrels present a significant advancement for the identification of polygonal rifled barrels. An examiner with knowledge of the machining methods, awareness of the possible subclass transfer and diminishing quality of these gross markings over time should still appropriately arrive at positive identifications and/or eliminations. The greater concern may be an examiner not familiar with these markings that relies on the gross characteristics alone for a positive identification. The Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory obtained 10 consecutively manufactured Glock EBIS Barrels to further explore the repeatability and uniqueness of striations/impressions, as well as the capability of identifying bullets fired through consecutively manufactured Glock EBIS Barrels. On a voluntary basis, 150 test sets were created and distributed to laboratories in forty-four states and nine countries. The test set was designed to determine an examiner+s ability to correctly identify bullets fired from 10 consecutively manufactured EBIS Barrels to test fired bullets fired from the same barrels. Additionally, this empirical study established an error rate of 0.4 percent.
Index Keywords: Enhanced Bullet Identification System (EBIS), error rate, Miami Barrel, National Academy of Sciences, polygonal, subclass

Title: Validation of Obturation Marks in Consecutively Reamed Chambers
Authors with affiliations: Brian Mayland and Caryn Tucker, Illinois State Police, Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A.
Author Keywords: The identification of fired cartridge cases to a particular firearm based on breech face markings and firing pin impressions has long been accepted in the field of firearms identification. Obturation marks have also been used to make identifications on fired cartridge cases; however, these types of patterns have not been validated as being reproducible and reliable. A nationwide study of obturation marks was conducted using test shots and unknowns from ten consecutively reamed chambers from three different manufacturers. The results show that obturation marks can be used to individualize a firearm.
Index Keywords: chamber marks, consecutively manufactured chambers, fireformed marks, obturation marks

Authors: Saribey A. Y., Grace Hannam A.G.
Title: Comparison of the Class and Individual Characteristics of Turkish 7.65mm Browning/.32 Automatic Caliber Self-Loading Pistols with Consecutive Serial Numbers
Affiliations: Ankara University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Engineering Physics, Tandoǧan 06100, Turkey; Forensic Science Service, Firearms Department, 109 Lambeth Road, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Yalçin Saribey, A., Ankara University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Engineering Physics, Tandoǧan 06100, Turkey; Grace Hannam, A., Forensic Science Service, Firearms Department, 109 Lambeth Road, London, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: Firearms identification is based on the fundamental principle that it is impossible to manufacture two identical items at the microscopic level. As firearm manufacturing technologies and quality assurance are improving, it is necessary to continually challenge this principle. In this study, two different makes of 7.65mm Browning/.32 Automatic caliber self-loading pistols of Turkish manufacture were selected and examined. Ten pistols with consecutive serial numbers were examined and each fired 10 times. The fired cartridge cases were recovered for comparison purposes. It was found that for each make of pistol, the individual characteristics within the firing pin impression, ejector, and breech face marks of all 10 pistols were found to be significantly different. © 2012 American Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Class characteristics; Comparison; Firearms identification; Forensic science; Individual characteristics; Pistol

Title: Non-Lead Rimfire Ammunition: New Problems For Examiners
Authors with affiliations: C. Rodney James, Ph.D. Independent Firearms Examiner, Fredericktown, Ohio
Author Keywords: This article summarizes the qualities of non-lead rimfire ammunition currently manufactured by CCI/Speer and Winchester. Specifically, the report summarizes aspects of the appearances of the engraved surfaces of these bullets after firing, with comparisons to earlier sintered iron bullets manufactured by Remington and Winchester. The .22 LR Winchester bullet, made of tin, takes matchable striae from rifling lands. Gas cutting of the bullet base indicates vaporization of tin which should be present in GSR from these bullets. Compressed powdered-copper LR bullets from CCI take no matchable striae. CCI TNT GREEN .22 JHP WMR takes matchable striae on the jacket, though the powdered copper core tends to cause major fragmentation of this bullet at short ranges.
Index Keywords: Ammunition, .22 caliber, Rimfire ammunition, CCI, Winchester, Remington, Bullet, Bullet material, Bullet identification, Cartridges, Rifling impressions, Green ammunition, Non-lead ammunition, Copper bullet, Tin bullet, Striae

Authors: Chumbley L.S., Kreiser J., Lizotte T., Ohar O., Grieve T., King B., Eisenmann D.
Title: Clarity of Microstamped Identifiers as a Function of Primer Hardness and Type of Firearm Action
Authors with affiliations: L.S. Chumbley 1, J. Kreiser 2, T. Lizotte 3, O. Ohar 3, T. Grieve 1, B. King 1, D. Eisenmann 11 Iowa State University, Ames Laboratory, Ames, Iowa 2 Illinois State Police, Retired, Springfield, Illinois 3 Pivotal Development, LLC, Manchester, NH
Author Keywords: The transfer of microstamped identifiers to the primers of fired cartridges was examined using a stereomicroscope and scanning electron microscope (SEM). The identifiers were placed on the firing pins of three different 9mm handguns, namely, a Sig Sauer, a Taurus, and a Hi-Point. Ten different brands of ammunition were fired from each handgun, 100 rounds being fired using each brand for a total of 1000 rounds fired per handgun. The quality of the markings was evaluated using a simple observation rubric. These results were compared to Vickers hardness values obtained from the ammunition primers and are discussed in light of the types of actions of firearms used.
Index Keywords: microstamping, primer hardness, stereomicroscope, recoil, blowback, toolmark

Authors: Grieve T., Chumbley L.S., Kreiser J., Lizotte T., Ohar O.
Title: Gear code extraction from microstamped cartridges
Affiliations: Iowa State University, Ames Laboratory Ames, Iowa, United States; Illinois State Police, Springfield, IL, United States; Pivotal Development, LLC, Manchester, NH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grieve, T., Iowa State University, Ames Laboratory Ames, Iowa, United States; Chumbley, L.S., Iowa State University, Ames Laboratory Ames, Iowa, United States; Kreiser, J., Illinois State Police, Springfield, IL, United States; Lizotte, T., Pivotal Development, LLC, Manchester, NH, United States; Ohar, O., Pivotal Development, LLC, Manchester, NH, United States
Author Keywords: The firing pins of three different handguns were modified to stamp a six-digit alpha-numeric code and a circumferential digital code known as a gear code into the primer of a cartridge when fired. In this paper the transfer of gear codes from firing pin to primers was evaluated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Only those cartridges that received poor clarity marks optically as regarding the alpha-numeric code were chosen for evaluation in the SEM. Photo editing software was employed to clearly outline and decipher the gear code around the circumference of the microstamped primer. Results show that the better imaging of the SEM allows more of the alpha-numeric identifiers to be distinguished as well as more of the gear code structure, however complete recognition is still not possible in all cases.
Index Keywords: Gear code; Microstamping; Scanning electron microscope

Title: Striated Marks on a Bullet Fires from a Smooth Bore Shotgun
Authors with affiliations: Shane Windsor, Texas Department of Public Safety, Austin, Texas
Author Keywords: This study illustrates that it is possible for a smooth bore firearm to produce striated patterns on bullets that are both reproducible and sufficient quantity to permit an identification by a trained examiner.
Index Keywords: striated, shotgun, smooth bore

Authors: Pendleton D., Sligh T., Wallace E.I.C.
Title: Identification of Three 000 Buck Pellets Fired from a Sawed-off .410 Bore Shotgun
Authors with affiliations: David Pendleton, Tammi Sligh, and Edward I. C. Wallace, Bexar County Criminal Investigation Laboratory, San Antonio, Texas.
Author Keywords: A recent homicide case submitted to the lab for examination included three 000 Buck pellets recovered at autopsy and a sawed-off .410 single-shot shotgun. Examination of the shotgun revealed a rough spot at the muzzle, which consistently marked test pellets fired from the shotgun. The autopsy pellets were subsequently identified as having been fired from the shotgun using these marks. The order of the pellets could also be determined by deformation indicating they all originated from a single shotshell.
Index Keywords: 000 Buck, identification, sawed-off, shotgun

Title: Possible Incorrect Elimination Caused By Deformation of a Projectile
Authors with affiliations: Brian Grabowski, Michigan State Police, Sterling Heights, U.S.A.
Author Keywords: The Thompson/Center Arms Contender model single shot pistol has a choke tube accessory available which allows .410 bore shot shells to be fired as well as .45 Colt ammunition. Firing the pistol using .45 Colt caliber ammunition with the choke tube attached produces a very different bullet from when the choke tube is not present. This situation could lead to an incorrect elimination if two bullets were examined or if the choke tube was not submitted with the firearm.
Index Keywords: Choke tube, Contender, Thompson/Center Arms

Title: The Identification of Fired 40mm Less Lethal Projectiles
Authors with affiliations: Shawn Malikowski, Oregon State Police Forensic Services Division, Springfield, Oregon
Author Keywords: During the course of analysis for an officer involved shooting, a less lethal 40mm launcher was test fired. Two 40mm rubber projectiles were recovered and were able to be identified to each other from rifling marks present on their plastic bases.
Index Keywords: identification, less lethal, 40mm

Title: The Identification of Fired Bullets Having Bearing Surfaces with General Contour Variations but Minimal Fine Striae
Authors with affiliations: Eric R. Collins, Deputy Sheriff-Criminalist, Office of the Sheriff, Contra Costa County, Forensic Services Division, Criminalistics Laboratory, Martinez, California, USA
Author Keywords: The author received a 7.62mm caliber Russian Nagant M1895 revolver for function testing and comparison to a series of questioned bullets that had been submitted to the laboratory in a homicide case. The questioned bullets had very poor quality rifling impressions that were devoid of nearly all fine striae. The bore of the submitted revolver contained an extremely large amount of lead fouling and produced markings on test-fired bullets having the same general appearance as the questioned bullets. Despite the minimal amount of fine striae on the questioned and test-fired bullets, the author was able to identify the questioned bullets as having been fired in the revolver based on the overall agreement that existed between the contour variations and axial engravings on the compared bullets and silicone casts from the revolver's bore.
Index Keywords: Aberrant rifling, age hardening, axial engravings, bald bullets, bore scope, casting, criteria for identification, fouling, gross contour variations, lead alloys, lead bullets, leaded bore, pattern matching, QCMS, Quantitative Consecutively Matching Stria

Title: The Significance of Chamber Throat Marks on Fired Bullets
Authors with affiliations: Nancy D. McCombs, California Department of Justice, Fresno CA USA
Author Keywords: Unusual marks were observed on the bearing surfaces of fired bullets. The striated marks were parallel to the axis of the bullets and not with the rifling, and were observed in various locations on the bullet's bearing surface. Upon further examination, the marks were determined to be caused by the chamber throats of various types of firearms. When subclass characteristic influence could be eliminated, the reproducible chamber throat marks were quite valuable in obtaining identifications when rifling marks were not of sufficient quality.
Index Keywords: Bullet, Chamber Throat, Chamber Throat Marks, Forcing Cone, Leade

Title: Non-Rifling Marks Found on Bullets
Authors with affiliations: Angel Moses, Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department, Las Vegas, Nevada
Author Keywords: Marks were noted on the bearing surface of bullets that were not the traditional type of marks used for bullet identification. The following reveals the considerations made and the actions taken to justify the use of the marks in determining the examiner's conclusion of identification and also that those nontraditional marks may also have some worth.
Index Keywords: bullet axis, barrel port, bullet seating, compensation, identifying mark on a bullet, non-rifling marks, throat marks

Title: An Ejection Port Mark On An Unfired 22 Magnum Cartridge
Authors with affiliations: Ian Bruce, Ballistics Unit, Scientific Section, Forensic Services Branch, Queensland Police Service, 200 Roma Street, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia 4000
Author Keywords: Examination of an unfired 22 Magnum cartridge collected from a shooting scene revealed a striated mark on the bullet ogive. The mark was found to be an ejection port mark and was identified to a 22 Magnum calibre Stirling Model 15 boltaction rifle.
Index Keywords: Ejection port marks, firearms identification, 22 Magnum

Title: Breechface Impressions Produced on Unfired Cartridges by Hi-Point Firearms
Authors with affiliations: Charles M. Clow, Tarrant County Medical Examiner's Office, Fort Worth, TX
Author Keywords: Chambering cartridges in Hi-Point pistols and carbines were found to produce identifiable breechface marks.

Title: Breechface Recess Marks Produced by Glock and Smith & Wesson Sigma Series Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Charles M. Clow, Tarrant County Medical Examiner's Office, Fort Worth, TX
Author Keywords: Reproducible cycling marks found on the rim of cartridge cases from Glock and Smith & Wesson Sigma Series pistols were found to be produced as the cartridge is released from the magazine lips and strikes the left underside corner of the of breechface recess.
Index Keywords: Glock, Smith & Wesson, Sigma, cycling marks, breechface recess

Title: Breechface Recess Marks on Cartridge Cases Discharged from 9mm Walther P99 Series Pistols and their Persistence
Authors with affiliations: Azahiri Azahidi 1, Rasyidi Harun 2 and R. Kuppuswamy 1, 1Forensic Science Programme, School of Health Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Health Campus, 16150 Kubang Kerian, Kelantan, Malaysia, 2Armourment Division, Logistics Department, Royal Malaysia P
Author Keywords: This report describes the breechface recess toolmarks noticed on Walther P99 pistols and their persistence. Experiments involving five Walther P99 pistols were conducted in order to determine the occurrence of changes of the marks on the cartridge cases after firing each pistol several hundreds of rounds. Results have shown that the breechface recess toolmarks (among others) retained their characteristics right from the first expended case to the last one. Quite significantly in one case these were the only marks available for characterization of the weapon.
Index Keywords: Walther P99 pistols, cartridge case, breechface recess toolmarks

Title: Cartridge Head Stamp Impression Transfer onto Breechface
Authors with affiliations: Pavel Kosachevsky, Israel National Police, Firearms Identification Laboratory
Author Keywords: The negative of a cartridge case head-stamp impression was discovered on the breech-face after test firing a rusty homemade submachine gun that was received in a case. Possible applications of this phenomenon are discussed.
Index Keywords: breechface, head-stamp transfer, impression, homemade, submachine gun, corrosion

Title: Carrier marks from a Maverick by Mossberg Model 88 Shotgun
Authors with affiliations: Michelle Hunsinger, Monroe County Public Safety Laboratory, Rochester, NY
Author Keywords: Recently a Maverick model 88 was submitted to the author+s lab along with several fired and unfired shotgun shells. During the examination of submitted fired and unfired shotgun shells striated marks were observed on the case heads. These marks were of interest as they were located on the interior diameter of the headstamp, near the primer cup. After conducting several tests with the submitted shotgun it was determined that these marks were made by the carrier.
Index Keywords: carrier/lifter marks, cycling marks, Maverick model 88, shotgun

Authors: Zidon Y., Koffman A., Hocherman G.
Title: Unique Firing Pin Hole Drag marks
Authors with affiliations: Yigal Zidon, Avi Koffman and Gil Hocherman, Firearms Identification Lab, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israeli Police
Author Keywords: This technical report will introduce, investigate and verify a set of individual characteristics, produced by the upper circumference edge of a firing pin hole of an FEG pistol model WALAM 48, caliber 380 ACP. These unique characteristics on new cartridges being loaded into the chamber have not been previously reported in professional literature and are introduced for use by firearm examiners.
Index Keywords: Firing pin hole, individual characteristics, FEG pistol

Authors: Giverts P., Schecter B., Hocherman G.
Title: Examination and Classification of Extraneous Marks on Discharged Bullets
Authors with affiliations: Pavel Giverts, Bernie Schecter and Gil Hocherman, Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS) Israel Police National HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Extraneous marks on projectiles, i.e., marks other than land and groove impressions, are shown and classified. By examining and classifying these markings, the examiner can provide the investigator with more detailed information. The markings described herein help create a more complete picture of the weapon and the crime scene.

Title: Identification of a Bullet Jacket to a Lead Core
Authors with affiliations: Charles M. Clow, Tarrant County Medical Examiner+s Office, Fort Worth, TX
Author Keywords: A toolmark present on a lead core is identified to test toolmarks created on sheet lead using a bullet jacket.

Title: Copper Disks from Prvi Partisan TMJ Bullets: Information of Forensic Interest
Authors with affiliations: Charles M. Clow, Office of the Tarrant County Medical Examiner, Fort Worth, TX, USA
Author Keywords: A case submitted to the laboratory led to the discovery of impressed toolmarks on a copper disk associated with Prvi Partisan 40 S&W caliber TMJ ammunition. This article describes how these marks might be used to identify a disk back to the jacket or the lead core from which they were originally assembled.
Index Keywords: Prvi Partisan, TMJ, copper disk

Title: The Effect of Subclass Characteristics Involving Shotgun Ammunition on IBIS Entries and Correlation Results
Authors with affiliations: Stephen R. Garten, IBIS Specialist and Michael T. Neel, Firearms and Toolmark Examiner, Department of Justice, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives Forensic Science Laboratory, Atlanta, GA
Author Keywords: Four experiments were conducted in order to determine the affect that subclass characteristics have on the correlation scores produced by the Integrated Ballistics Identification System (IBIS). Specifically, parallel manufacturing marks, which are present on the primers of certain lots and brands of 12 gauge shotgun ammunition, were examined. Since IBIS only 'sees' shades of gray and cannot tell that markings are or are not individual in nature, the responsibility falls on the examiner to thoroughly check all ammunition prior to use in casework. Before any experimentation, several brands of ammunition were examined for the presence of manufacturing marks. Then, in each of the four experiments, variables were tested in order to determine the affect that these marks have on the IBIS correlation process. Failure of the technician to recognize these markings on the ammunition prior to test firing a weapon and acquiring images can cause IBIS to erroneously treat subclass characteristics as individual ones.
Index Keywords: Correlation, IBIS, Subclass Characteristics

Title: Interesting Characteristics of Golden Bear Brand 30-06 Cartridges
Authors with affiliations: Evan Thompson, Arizona Department of Public Safety, Flagstaff, AZ 86001 United States
Author Keywords: Striated marks found on the unfired primers of 30-06 caliber Golden Bear ammunition remained after having been fired. Without knowing that these marks were made during the manufacturing process, these marks could potentially be misidentified as having been produced during the firing process.
Index Keywords: 30-06, depressed ring, Golden Bear, loading marks, primer, striations, subclass

Title: Manufacturing Marks on Speer Cartridges
Authors with affiliations: By: Technical Leader / Senior Forensic Scientist Michael S. Ward & Senior Forensic Scientist Victoria Van Fleet, Fort Worth Police Department Crime Laboratory, Firearms & Toolmark Unit, Fort Worth, Texas.
Author Keywords: During the initial examination of evidence Speer 45 Auto cartridge cases, toolmarks were observed on the heads of the cartridge cases that appeared similar to breech face marks; however, a more in depth examination of the cartridge cases quickly revealed that the toolmarks on the heads of the cartridge cases could not be breech face marks. The tool marks on the head of the cartridge cases were in alignment even when the firing pin drag marks on the cartridge cases were not in alignment. Further examination revealed that it was possible to identify the tool marks on the heads of the evidence cartridge cases to the tool marks located on the heads of Speer 45 Auto cartridges located in the Laboratory ammunition supply.Buy Journal (non-members) Buy this Article ($5) (non-members)Members login to view.

Authors: LaCova S., Fox J., Mattia N.
Title: Subclass Characteristics on CCI Speer Cartridge Case Heads
Authors with affiliations: Detective Salvatore LaCova, Detective Jonathan Fox and Forensic Consultant Nicholas Mattia, New York Police Department, Forensic Investigations Division, Police Crime Laboratory, Firearms Analysis Section, Jamaica, New York.
Author Keywords: Microscopic examination and comparison of evidence CCI Speer discharged cartridge case heads revealed unusual, yet similar, striation patterns from different crime scenes. These subclass characteristics have been found on a variety of evidence caliber casings as well as unfired cartridges from the NYPD ammunition supply. This phenomenon was investigated and a common source was identified.

Title: Irregular Impressions on 9mm Luger Caliber Winchester Primers - Not Subclass Characteristics
Authors with affiliations: Detective Salvatore LaCova and Forensic Consultant Nicholas Mattia, New York Police Department, Forensic Investigations Division, Police Laboratory, Firearms Analysis Section, Jamaica, New York.
Author Keywords: Preliminary examination for the presences of subclass marks on new ammunition delivered to the New York City Police Department Firearms Analysis Section revealed unusual impressions found on some 9mm Luger caliber Winchester primers. (Figures 1 and 2) The impressions were similar in appearance and located on the center area of the primers. Although they are macroscopic, these consistent yet irregular impressions failed to meet the criteria for the AFTE definition of "Subclass Characteristics."
Index Keywords: Packer, Packaging, and Subclass Characteristics

Title: The Presence of Raised Concentric Rings on CCI Blazer Brand Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: Evan Thompson, Arizona Department of Public Safety, Flagstaff, AZ 86001 United States
Author Keywords: Raised concentric rings were noted using oblique lighting on unfired and fired CCI Blazer brand cartridge cases. The rings were found to be the result, under certain circumstances, of the manufacturing process.
Index Keywords: aluminum, Blazer, cartridge case, CCI, concentric, latent prints, raised rings

Title: Identification of Production Toolmakrs Inside Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: Lars Hebsgaard, Detective Inspector, Danish National Police. National Centre of Forensic Services, Firearms and Crime Scene Unit.
Author Keywords: In many crimes where a firearm has been used, the weapon used cannot lead to a possible offender if the weapon has been hidden or lost. However, if cartridges are found during the search of a suspect's residence, a comparison of the cartridge cases from a crime scene can be performed using production toolmarks. As a result, a firearms examiner can determine if these cartridges originate from the same production line, within a relatively short period of time. Although the toolmarks can be used as a supplemental analysis which increases the strength of the evidence, it cannot be used to prove that cartridge cases from a crime scene are the same as those found in subsequent searches of a suspect. As a result, a match of these marks merely increases the probability cartridges come from the same production line. Here, we will look at some of the tool marks that are left during the commercial production of cartridge cases. In particular, we will look at 2 or 3 distinct process which leave evidentiary traces that can be used for forensic identification of fired and unfired cartridge cases.
Index Keywords: identification, production toolmarks, inside cartridge cases

Title: The Effect of the Machining Process as it Relates to Toolmarks on Surfaces
Authors with affiliations: Chris Monturo, Miami Valley Regional Crime Laboratory, Dayton, OH
Author Keywords: It is an accepted scientific principal that machined items are individual in nature. The underlying factors which cause the individuality of machined items, even between consecutively manufactured items, can be attributed to characteristics of both the tool and the metal being cut. The variables which cause the individuality of a machined surface are discussed.
Index Keywords: Machining, toolmarks, milling, individual characteristics

Title: The Mechanics of the Grinding Process
Authors with affiliations: Chris Monturo, Miami Valley Regional Crime Laboratory, Dayton, OH
Author Keywords: Grinding is the fundamental method in making the tools that make other tools, such as endmills and drills. It is also a process that is used in finishing and sharpening other tools such as screwdrivers, diagonal cutters, and knives. Understanding the complex and random nature of the grinding process is essential to understanding the effect that it has on producing individual characteristics. The variables which cause the individuality of a ground surface is discussed.
Index Keywords: grinding, machining, toolmarks, individual characteristics

Title: Method of Rifling by Manufacturer
Authors with affiliations: Jaimie Smith, Maryland State Police Department Crime Laboratory, Pikesville, MD USA

Title: Manufacturing of SIG Sauer 9 x 19 mm Pistols

Author Keywords: This article details the manufacturing processes and assembly of 9 x 19 mm calibre SIG Sauer duty, sporting and limited edition pistols produced at the factory in Eckernforde, Germany. The principal manufacturing focus for this paper is SIG Sauer barrel production, as two methods of rifling are utilized in their pistols; electrochemical rifling and cold hammer forged rifling. Title: Metal injection molded strikers and extractors in a Smith & Wesson model M&P pistol
Affiliations: Monroe County Crime Laboratory, Firearms and Toolmark Section, Rochester, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hunsinger, M., Monroe County Crime Laboratory, Firearms and Toolmark Section, Rochester, NY, United States
Author Keywords: During the summer of 2009, Smith & Wesson (S&W) began selling their M&P model pistols with metal injection molded (MIM) strikers. Currently, all calibers except the .45 use such strikers, but all M&P pistols contain MIM manufactured extractors. Five MIM strikers and extractors were obtained from S&W. Firing pin impressions, firing pin drag marks and extractor marks were used to compare class and individual characteristics within these markings, to assess the potential of subclass characteristics, as well as the durability of the working surfaces.
Index Keywords: Electropolishing; Extractor; Firing pin impression; Metal injection molding; MIM; Smith and Wesson model M and P; Striker

Title: Para-Ordnance (Para USA) Company and Manufacturing Information
Authors with affiliations: J. Justine Kreso, Onondaga County Center for Forensic Sciences, Syracuse, NY, Jennifer Coombs, Erie County Central Police Services Forensic Laboratory
Author Keywords: Several firearm and tool mark examiners were able to tour the Para-Ordnance Manufacturing Company facility in 2008. The factory tour provided company information and manufacturing techniques and specifications that may be useful to firearm and tool mark examiners.

Title: AFTE Glossary, 5th Edition
The Potential for and Persistence of Subclass Chracteristics on the Breech Faces of SW40VE Smith & Wesson Sigma Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Laura Lightstone, Metropolitan Police Department (MPD), Washington, DC, USA
Author Keywords: An article published in the 2007 AFTE Journal Summer edition discusses a situation in which a high degree of subclass characteristics were found in two firearms during routine casework. Gene Rivera of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department Crime Laboratory describes how these two firearms came to be discovered through the use of NIBIN, and reemphasizes the importance of the firearms examiner's job to be able to recognize and distinguish subclass characteristics when present. It was this striking case that prompted further research into the propensity and persistence of subclass characteristics in the Sigma Series line, and the potential for individuality to be established on these firearms.

Authors with affiliations: Steve Kramer, St. Louis County Police Crime Laboratory, St. Louis, Missouri

Authors: Pauw-Vugts P., Walters A., Øren L., Pfoser L.
Title: FAID2009: Proficiency test and workshop
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute, The Hague, Netherlands; Metropolitan Police Service, London, United Kingdom; Kripos, Oslo, Norway; Bundeskriminalamt, Wiesbaden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pauw-Vugts, P., Netherlands Forensic Institute, The Hague, Netherlands; Walters, A., Metropolitan Police Service, London, United Kingdom; Øren, L., Kripos, Oslo, Norway; Pfoser, L., Bundeskriminalamt, Wiesbaden, Germany
Author Keywords: A Firearms Identification proficiency test and follow-up workshop was arranged in 2009/2010 within the framework of the ENFSI (European Network of Forensic Science Institutes) Expert Working Group Firearms/GSR. The proficiency test was called FAID2009 (FireArms IDentification 2009). The test consisted of ten sets of samples, five with bullets and five with cartridge cases. Each set consisted of three items: one unknown item and two items from a known firearm. In five of the test sets, the unknown and the known items were from different firearms. All the items for each test set were polymer castings from the same original fired bullets and cartridge cases. In this way, all the examiners from the different laboratories were given the opportunity to examine identical marks. The test sets were sent to 68 forensic laboratories (table 1), mostly in Europe (61), and examiners were asked to compare the unknown item in each test set with the known items, and choose a conclusion from a virtual scale with 5 (+1) levels ranging rom identification to exclusion / elimination, with a level available for "unsuitable". Sixty-four laboratories returned the answer form, and 637 conclusions were given. Twenty-six conclusions (4%) were false identifications and thirteen conclusions (2%) were false exclusions. Forty-three of the laboratories attended the follow-up workshop, where the results were discussed.
Index Keywords: FAID2005; FAID2009; False exclusions; False identifications; Proficiency test; Subclass characteristics

Authors: Song J., Vorburger T.V., Thompson R., Ballou S., Zheng A., Renegar T.B., Silver R.M.
Title: Topography Measurements and Performance Comparisons between NIST SRM 2460 Standard Bullet Masters and BKA Bullet Replicas
Authors with affiliations: J. Song, T.V. Vorburger, R. Thompson, S. Ballou, A. Zheng, T.B. Renegar, R. Silver National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, U.S.A., M. Ols Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), Ammendale, MD 20705
Author Keywords: Polymer replication potentially provides an alternative technology to producing a second series of the Standard Reference Material (SRM) bullets produced by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). To test this potential, two SRM 2460 bullets were used as masters for the fabrication of replica bullets at the Federal Criminal Police Office, Bundeskriminalamt (BKA). The surface topography of the SRM masters and the replicas were measured and compared to determine their topography similarity. The topography comparisons revealed surface contamination of a replica bullet made from the first SRM bullet master. However, the surface contamination problem was significantly improved with a replica bullet made from the second SRM bullet master. To compare the performance similarity of imaging correlations, one of the replica bullets was imaged at the National Laboratory Center of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) using an Integrated Ballistics Identification System (IBIS)*. The image of the replica bullet was correlated with those of the SRM bullets previously tested from 2002 to 2006. The Max Phase correlation scores were used for performance comparisons. There was no significant difference in the imaging performance between the SRM bullets and the replica bullet.
Index Keywords: ballistics identification, bullet replica, forensic science, IBIS, NIBIN, standard bullet, standard reference material, SRM

Authors: Barrett M., Tajbakhsh A., Warren G.
Title: Portable Forensic Ballistics Examination Instrument: Advanced Ballistic Analysis System (ALIAS)
Authors with affiliations: Michael Barrett, President Pyramidal Technologies Ltd., Barbados and former Forensic Firearms Examiner for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police; Ardavan Tajbakhsh, CTO Pyramidal Technologies Ltd., Barbados; and Gaylan Warren, Columbia International Forensics
Author Keywords: A portable, measurement instrument and analysis tool for use by forensic ballistics and firearms examiners that creates, compares and analyses three-dimensional, volumetric models of fired cartridge cases and spent bullets. The technology can measure and examine toolmarks as small as two microns. ALIAS includes computer hardware, an open database infrastructure, a high-precision, Swiss-built, application-specific interferometer with a (six-pac+ cartridge case or expended bullet holder (patents pending) and an open software architecture.

Authors: Gerules G., Bhatia S.K., Jackson D.E.
Title: A survey of image processing techniques and statistics for ballistic specimens in forensic science
Affiliations: Department of Math and Computer Science, University of Missouri-St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63121, United States; Police Crime Laboratory, St. Louis County Police, Clayton, MO 63105, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gerules, G., Department of Math and Computer Science, University of Missouri-St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63121, United States; Bhatia, S.K., Department of Math and Computer Science, University of Missouri-St. Louis, St. Louis, MO 63121, United States; Jackson, D.E., Police Crime Laboratory, St. Louis County Police, Clayton, MO 63105, United States
Author Keywords: This paper provides a review of recent investigations on the image processing techniques used to match spent bullets and cartridge cases. It is also, to a lesser extent, a review of the statistical methods that are used to judge the uniqueness of fired bullets and spent cartridge cases. We review 2D and 3D imaging techniques as well as many of the algorithms used to match these images. We also provide a discussion of the strengths and weaknesses of these methods for both image matching and statistical uniqueness. The goal of this paper is to be a reference for investigators and scientists working in this field. © 2012 Forensic Science Society.

Authors: Bolton-King R.S., Evans J.P.O., Smith C.L.
Title: What are the Prospects of 3D Profiling Systems Applied to Firearms and Toolmarks Identification?
Authors with affiliations: Rachel S Bolton-King1, J Paul O Evans1, Clifton L Smith2, Jonathon D Painter3, Derek F Allsop3 and Wayne M Cranton1 1. School of Science and Technology, Nottingham Trent University, Nottingham NG11 8NS, UK. 2. School of Computing and Security Science, Edi
Author Keywords: This paper details a comparative pilot study of 3D (three dimensional) imaging technologies for potential application in forensic firearms and toolmark identification; as such it reviews the most up-to-date profiling systems. In particular, the paper focuses on the application of 3D imaging and recording technology as applied to firearm identification, being a specialised field within the discipline of toolmark identification. Each technology under test employs a different technique or scientific principle to capture topographic data i.e. focus-variation microscopy, confocal microscopy, point laser profilometry and vertical scanning interferometry. To qualitatively establish the capabilities and limitations of each technology investigated, standard reference samples were used and a set of specific operational criteria devised for successful application in this field. The reference standard crucially included and centred on was the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) 'standard bullet'. This was to ensure that evaluation represented the practical examination of ballistic samples i.e. fired cartridge cases and bullets. It is concluded that focus-variation microscopy has potentially the most promising approach for a forensic laboratory instrument, in terms of functionality and 3D imaging performance, and is worthy of further investigation.
Index Keywords: 3D imaging, bullet, cartridge case, confocal microscopy, firearms identification, focus-variation microscopy,forensic ballistics, laser triangulation, optical profilometry,point laser profilometry, striae, stylus profilometry, toolmarks

Author Keywords: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is a useful tool for comparison of impressed or striated toolmarks, particularly those occurring on rimfire and center fire cartridge cases and for striated marks on bullets. The depth of field is far superior to a light microscope and the object does not have to be side lighted to visualize topography. Some applications of SEM for comparison of firing pin impressions and toolmarks are presented.

Authors: Chu W., Song J., Vorburger T., Ballou S.
Title: Striation density for predicting the identifiability of fired bullets with automated inspection systems
Affiliations: National Institute of Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8212, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8212, United States; Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China
Authors with affiliations: Chu, W., National Institute of Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8212, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8212, United States, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China; Song, J., National Institute of Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8212, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8212, United States; Vorburger, T., National Institute of Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8212, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8212, United States; Ballou, S., National Institute of Standards and Technology, 100 Bureau Drive, Stop 8212, Gaithersburg, MD 20899-8212, United States
Author Keywords: Automated firearms identification systems will correlate a reference bullet with all evidence bullets without a selection procedure to exclude the bullets having insufficient bullet identifying signature. Correlations that include such bullets increase the workload and may affect the correlation accuracy. In this article, a parameter called striation density is proposed for determining and predicting bullet identifiability. After image preprocessing, edge detection and filtering techniques are used to extract the edges of striation marks, the resulting binary image distinctly shows the amount and distribution of striation marks. Then striation density is calculated for determining the quality of images. In the experiment, striation densities for six lands of 48 bullets fired from 12 gun barrels of six manufactures are calculated. Statistical results show strong relation between striation density and identification rate. It can provide firearms identification systems with a quantitative criterion to assess whether there are sufficient striae for reliable bullet identification. © 2010 American Academy of Forensic Sciences. Published 2010. This article is a U.S. Government work and is in the public domain in the U.S.A.
Index Keywords: edge detection; firearms identification; forensic science; identifiability; morphology; striation density

Title: Cartridge case image matching using effective correlation area based method
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Naresuan University, 99 Moo 9, Phisanulok 65000, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Yammen, S., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Naresuan University, 99 Moo 9, Phisanulok 65000, Thailand; Muneesawang, P., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Naresuan University, 99 Moo 9, Phisanulok 65000, Thailand
Author Keywords: A firearm leaves a unique impression on fired cartridge cases. The cross-correlation function plays an important role in matching the characteristic features on the cartridge case found at the crime scene with a specific firearm, for accurate firearm identification. This paper proposes that the computational forensic techniques of alignment and effective correlation area-based approaches to image matching are essential to firearm identification. Specifically, the reference and the corresponding cartridge cases are aligned according to the phase-correlation criterion on the transform domain. The informative segments of the breech face marks are identified by a cross-covariance coefficient using the coefficient value in a window located locally in the image space. The segments are then passed to the measurement of edge density for computing effective correlation areas. Experimental results on a new dataset show that the correlation system can make use of the best properties of alignment and effective correlation area-based approaches, and can attain significant improvement of image-correlation results, compared with the traditional image-matching methods for firearm identification, which employ cartridge-case samples. An analysis of image-alignment score matrices suggests that all translation and scaling parameters are estimated correctly, and contribute to the successful extraction of effective correlation areas. It was found that the proposed method has a high discriminant power, compared with the conventional correlator. This paper advocates that this method will enable forensic science to compile a large-scale image database to perform correlation of cartridge case bases, in order to identify firearms that involve pairwise alignments and comparisons. © 2013 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Cartridge case image matching; Cross-correlation function; Edge density measurement; Effective correlation area; Firearm identification; Image registration
Correspondence Address: accuracy; article; ballistics; cartridge case image matching; firearm; forensic science; imaging system; priority journal

Authors: Sakarya U., Topçu O., Leloĝlu U.M., Soysal M., Tunali E.
Title: Automated region segmentation on cartridge case base
Affiliations: TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Sakarya, U., TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey; Topçu, O., TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey; Leloĝlu, U.M., TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey; Soysal, M., TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey; Tunali, E., TüBITAK UZAY, ODTü Yerleşkesi, 06531 Ankara, Turkey
Author Keywords: One of the significant problems encountered in criminology studies is the successful automated matching of fired cartridge cases, on the basis of the characteristic marks left on them by firearms. An intermediate step in the solution of this problem is the segmentation of certain regions that are defined on the cartridge case base. This paper describes a model-based method that performs segmentation of the cartridge case using surface height image of a center fire cartridge case base. The proposed method detects the location of the cartridge case base center and specific circular contours around it iteratively by projecting the problem to a one-dimensional feature space. In addition, the firing pin impression region is determined by utilizing an adaptive threshold that differentiates impression marks form primer region surface. Letters on the cartridge case base are also detected by using surface modeling and adaptive thresholding, in order to render the surface comparison operation robust against irrelevant surface features. Promising experimental results indicate the eligibility of the proposed method to be used for automated cartridge case base region segmentation process. © 2012 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Automated firearms identification; Automated region segmentation; Cartridge case base; Forensic science
Correspondence Address: article; automation; bullet; cartridge; chemical analysis; criminology; firearm; forensic science; human; illumination; information processing; methodology; morphology; motivation; priority journal; process optimization; reinforcement

Authors: Monkres J., Luckie C., Petraco N.D.K., Milam A.
Title: Comparison and statistical analysis of land impressions from consecutively rifled barrels
Affiliations: Virginia Commonwealth University, Department of Forensic Science, 4609 Emmett Road, Glen Allen, VA, 23060, United States; Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Forensic Sciences, 830 Southampton Avenue, Suite 400, Norfolk, VA 23510, United States; John Jay College of Criminal Justice and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, 899 10th Avenue, New York, NY 10019, United States
Authors with affiliations: Monkres, J., Virginia Commonwealth University, Department of Forensic Science, 4609 Emmett Road, Glen Allen, VA, 23060, United States; Luckie, C., Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Forensic Sciences, 830 Southampton Avenue, Suite 400, Norfolk, VA 23510, United States; Petraco, N.D.K., John Jay College of Criminal Justice and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, 899 10th Avenue, New York, NY 10019, United States; Milam, A., Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Forensic Sciences, 830 Southampton Avenue, Suite 400, Norfolk, VA 23510, United States
Author Keywords: The validity and reliability of firearm and toolmark analysis has been debated, often revolving around the subjectivity of the methods examiners use. This study attempts to confirm an examiner's conclusions through objective computer analysis. Bullets, knowns and unknowns, fired through ten consecutively rifled barrels were used for the study. Unknown bullets were identified to the barrels from which they had been fired using traditional comparison techniques. Each land impression (LI) was photographed, and the distances of the prominent striae to one shoulder of the (LI) were measured using computer software. Two methods of selecting measurable striae were used. The data from these measurements was then converted into a barcode representative of the LI from which it was taken. Barcodes were subjected to Principle Component Analysis (PCA), and a Support Vector Machine (SVM) was employed to evaluate the computer's ability to correctly identify which LI was represented by the barcode, based on SVM analysis error rate (ideal error rate ≤5%). Optimal error rate varied based on selection technique, with 19.444% and 1.149% being the optimal values obtained by each method. The second result, generated by the majority of bullets analyzed, indicated the computer was able to adequately group barcodes according to their common origins, supporting the examiner's identifications. This research and described methodology may provide support for the reliability of firearm and toolmark analysis.
Index Keywords: Barcoding; Consecutively rifled barrels; Firearm; Forensic science; Pattern recognition; Principle component analysis; Support vector machine; Toolmark

Authors: Song J., Vorburger T.V., Ballou S., Thompson R.M., Yen J., Renegar T.B., Zheng A., Silver R.M., Ols M.
Title: The National Ballistics Imaging Comparison (NBIC) project
Affiliations: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), Ammendale, MD 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Song, J., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Vorburger, T.V., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Ballou, S., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Thompson, R.M., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Yen, J., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Renegar, T.B., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Zheng, A., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Silver, R.M., National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Ols, M., Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), Ammendale, MD 20705, United States
Author Keywords: In response to the guidelines issued by the American Society of Crime Laboratory Directors/Laboratory Accreditation Board (ASCLD/LAB-International) to establish traceability and quality assurance in U.S. crime laboratories, a NIST/ATF joint project entitled National Ballistics Imaging Comparison (NBIC) was initialized in 2008. The NBIC project aims to establish a National Traceability and Quality System for ballistics identifications in crime laboratories within the National Integrated Ballistics Information Network (NIBIN) of the U.S. NIST Standard Reference Material (SRM) 2460 bullets and 2461 cartridge cases are used as reference standards. 19 ballistics examiners from 13 U.S. crime laboratories participated in this project. They each performed 24 periodic image acquisitions and correlations of the SRM bullets and cartridge cases over the course of a year, but one examiner only participated in Phase 1 tests of SRM cartridge case. The correlation scores were collected by NIST for statistical analyses, from which control charts and control limits were developed for the proposed Quality System and for promoting future assessments and accreditations for firearm evidence in U.S. forensic laboratories in accordance with the ISO 17025 Standard. © 2011.
Index Keywords: Ballistics identification; Forensic science; NBIC; NIBIN; Standard bullet; Standard cartridge case; Standard reference material

Authors: Schecter B., Siso R., Giverts P., Hocherman G.
Title: Underside Ejector Marks From Glock Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Bernie Schecter, Rafi Siso, Pavel Giverts and Gil Hocherman, Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel Police National HQ, Jerusalem.
Author Keywords: Two types of pistols - Glock and S&W Sigma are very easily confused in attempted identifications via their expended cartridge cases. We have found a definitive difference between the two types of pistols via the underside ejector mark present on cartridge cases discharged in Glock pistols and absent on cartridge cases from S&W Sigma pistols. Testing of various models and calibers of both Glock and Sigma pistols has been undertaken to verify this.
Index Keywords: Glock, Smith & Wesson, Sigma, ejector, cartridge case

Title: Tavor Assault Rifle - TAR 21
Authors with affiliations: Pavel Kosachevsky and Lionel Bokobza, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Tavor is a bullpup assault rifle that was developed in Israel and introduced in the late 1990s. It is standard issue in some divisions of the Israeli military, and is sold around the world. The purpose of this research is to investigate and present Tavor's class characteristics. Fifteen Tavor rifles were test fired; all marks on cartridge cases were documented, studied and their comparison value was assessed. The paper presents and discusses the differences and similarities between Tavor and M-16 class characteristics. The neck mark, a unique class characteristic of Tavor is described.
Index Keywords: Tavor, TAR-21, bullpup, M-16, class characteristics, firing pin impression, extractor mark, ejector mark, cutout marks, neck mark, lug marks, chamber marks, ejection port marks, breechface impression, Right-handed configuration, Left-handed configuration

Title: Firearms Sound Level Measurements - Suppressed and Unsuppressed Firearms, Supersonic Bullets, and Comparable High Amplitude Impulse Sounds Part 3
Authors with affiliations: Lucien C. Haag, Forensic Science Services P.O. Box 5347 Carefree, AZ 85377
Author Keywords: Only a limited number of modern Sound Pressure Level (SPL) meters are capable of accurately measuring the peak decibel (dB) levels of gunshots and other impulse sounds. Part 1 of this series described the requirements for such meters and the use of a control firearm-ammunition combination as a practical means of verifying proper performance of an SPL meter. Part 2 described and illustrated the effects of a number of variables on dB measurements. These included barrel length, subsonic vs. supersonic discharges, muzzle pressure, microphone position, microphone standoff distance, scale selection and environmental variations. In this final Part 3, some examples are presented of suppressed and unsuppressed firearms fitted with professionally made suppressors and homemade suppressors. The matter of the sound levels of supersonic bullets in flight that pass near downrange ear witnesses is provided. Finally, several examples of common high amplitude impulse sounds are also provided to which courts and juries can relate when presented with testimony regarding the sound level of gunshots.
Index Keywords: decibel, dB, gunshots, handclap, Larson-Davis 800B, MIL-STD-1474D, paper bag bursts, SPL, sound level meter, supersonic shockwave, test comparisons, test parameters, test variables, toy balloon bursts

Title: Three Cases of Recovering Laser Engraved Serial Numbers of Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Lad+rio da Silva (1),(a), Paulo Acioly Marques dos Santos (2),(b), Andrea Porto Carreiro Campos (3), (c) and Vilma Jorge Abib (4):(1) Departamento de Ffsica do Instituto de CiOncias Exatas (ICEx) da Universidade Federal Fluminense. Rua Desembargador Ellis
Author Keywords: Three cases are presented in which obliterated laser engraved serial numbers of pistols were recovered. The acid etching techniques used to restore stamped serial numbers do not work well for laser etched serial numbers in aluminum alloy frames. Many of the Brazilian Police Forces are now carrying Taurus pistols with aluminum alloy frames with laser etched serial numbers with a depth of about 75m. The grinding and polishing steps of the acid etching techniques may remove the remaining information.
Index Keywords: laser engraving, serial number restoration

Title: History, Development, and Types of Airguns, with a Forensic Study of Big Bore Airguns Part II
Authors with affiliations: Stacey Phetteplace, Forensic Scientist II, Texas Department of Public Safety, Tyler Regional Crime Laboratory, Tyler, Texas
Author Keywords: Although airguns in general and big bore airguns have been very popular in Europe, a new surge in popularity of big bore airguns in the United States prompted this research paper. Big bore airguns have been used for centuries for warfare and hunting big game animals. Currently, they can be accurately and repeatedly fired up to 300 yards in favorable conditions. The history and development of pneumatic big bore airguns are explored from a forensic viewpoint in part one, and manufacturing with a basic study of two models is discussed in part two. In part one of this article, the history, power systems and muzzle and recoil energies were discussed. In the second part, basic research of how big bore airguns are manufactured in the United States is discussed and includes an initial forensic study of two popular American made Big Bore Airguns. Part Two concludes with examples of the most popular Big Bore airguns.
Index Keywords: Airguns, airgun energy, airgun history, airgun power sources, Barnes air rifles, big bore airguns, Girandoni airguns, multi-pump airguns, pre-charged pneumatic airguns, Quackenbush air rifles, single stroke airguns, spring airguns

Title: Unintentional firearm hunting deaths in Sweden
Affiliations: Section of Forensic Medicine, Department of Community Medicine and Rehabilitation, Umeå University, POB 7616, SE-907 12 Umeå, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Junuzovic, M., Section of Forensic Medicine, Department of Community Medicine and Rehabilitation, Umeå University, POB 7616, SE-907 12 Umeå, Sweden; Eriksson, A., Section of Forensic Medicine, Department of Community Medicine and Rehabilitation, Umeå University, POB 7616, SE-907 12 Umeå, Sweden
Author Keywords: This study examined all unintentional firearm fatalities while hunting that occurred in Sweden between 1983 through 2008. The circumstances as well as the impact of the hunter's exam on fatality frequency were analysed. During these 26 years, there were 48 such fatalities, representing 53% of all (n=90) unintentional firearm deaths during the same period. The average annual number of fatalities decreased over the last few decades. Very restrictive firearm legislation in Sweden combined with the introduction of a mandatory hunter's exam since 1985 accounted, at least partly, for this finding. Moose hunting accounted for 46% of the fatalities and small game hunting for the remaining cases. The mean age of the victims was 50 years and 96% of them were males; all shooters were males. During moose hunting, most of the victims were mistaken for game, whereas in small game hunting most of the fatalities were related to falls and improper handling of the weapon. Human error was thus the main cause of these fatalities. © 2011 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Firearm; Hunting; Unintentional deaths

Authors: Thompson M.C., Lancaster C.A., Banta M.G., Hart C.N., Scanlan M.D., Espinoza E.O.
Title: Chemical Properties of Selected Plastic-Tipped Bullets
Authors with affiliations: Melisa C. Thompson, Cady A. Lancaster, Michele G. Banta, Crystal N. Hart, Michael D. Scanlan, and Edgard O. Espinoza U.S. Fish and Wildlife National Forensics Laboratory 1490 East Main Street, Ashland, Oregon 97520-1310
Author Keywords: Fragments of plastic-tipped bullets are often found in wound tracts of unlawfully killed wildlife. Using color, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy analysis coupled to the statistical power of discriminate analysis and x-ray fluorescence spectrometry, we were able to characterize the polymers found in common commercially available plastic-tipped bullets. The data is surprising because the high quality control used by the manufacturers provides an opportunity for forensic class character determination.Buy Journal (non-members) Buy this Article ($5) (non-members)Members login to view.

Title: Bullets fragments identification by comparison of their chemical composition obtained using instrumental neutron activation analysis
Affiliations: MAT-STG, ENEA (Italian National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Economically Sustainable Development), Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Sedda, A.F., MAT-STG, ENEA (Italian National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Economically Sustainable Development), Rome, Italy; Rossi, G., MAT-STG, ENEA (Italian National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Economically Sustainable Development), Rome, Italy
Author Keywords: Bullets found in crime scenes are usually compared by examination of the rifling impressions produced in the barrel of the questioned firearm. When, however, a bullet is fragmented or highly deformed, the comparison of rifling micro striations cannot be performed, and the only way two compare two or more bullets is by a match of their chemical analysis. In spite of the limits of the chemical analysis methods, due to the frequent compositional lead variability of ammunition boxes, the technique still keeps its full value, both as trial element, and as an aid in the investigations. A case is reported in the present paper, in which some crushed and deformed bullets, recovered from a murder victim body, have been analyzed by Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis. The analysis allowed the assignation of the bullets to one of the ammunitions lots owned by one of the murder suspect. © 2010 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: 0.22 Ammunition; Bullet analysis; INAA; Lead analysis

Authors: Thomas D., Carr D.J., Malbon C., Tichler C.
Title: Within- and BetweenBatch Variation of 9 x 19 mm FMJ Ammunition
Authors with affiliations: D. Thomas 1, D. J. Carr 1, C. Malbon 2 and C. Tichler 2, 1 Impact and Armour Group, Department of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Cranfield Defence and Security, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, Wiltshire, SN6 8LA
Author Keywords: There is a paucity of information in the peer-reviewed literature on the variability of bullet properties (e.g. dimensions, mass, composition, hardness). The aim of this work was to develop a methodology to investigate the within- and betweenbatch variation in physical and mechanical properties of 9 x 19 mm full metal jacket (DM1 1A1B2) ammunition. The variation in properties is of interest for two reasons i) variability as a test piece because all UK Police body armour provides protection from it and ii) variability with respect to batch identification for recovered bullets and fragments of bullets, and / or cartridge cases. In this work a selection protocol for sampling from batches of ammunition was developed and tested. Non-destructive and destructive techniques were investigated for determining the variability of ammunition from two batches. Data obtained were statistically analysed. XRF of the bullet core was a good technique for determining variability between batches, but required the bullet to be sectioned, or to have fragmented. Measuring the length of the whole round and its mass was the most useful method with respect to minimising variability of ammunition as a test piece.Buy Journal (non-members) Buy this Article ($5) (non-members)Members login to view.
Index Keywords: dimensions, mass, X-ray fluorescence, body armour, bullet, cartridge case

Title: The Identification of Two Unusual Types of Homemade Ammunition
Affiliations: Department of Forensic Science, Central Police University, 56 Shujen Road, Takang Village, Kueishan Hsiang, Taoyuan County 33304, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.-C., Department of Forensic Science, Central Police University, 56 Shujen Road, Takang Village, Kueishan Hsiang, Taoyuan County 33304, Taiwan; Meng, H.-H., Department of Forensic Science, Central Police University, 56 Shujen Road, Takang Village, Kueishan Hsiang, Taoyuan County 33304, Taiwan
Author Keywords: Illegal homemade ammunition is commonly used by criminals to commit crimes in Taiwan. Two unusual types of homemade ammunition that most closely resembling genuine ammunition are studied here. Their genuine counterparts are studied as the control samples for the purpose of comparison. Unfired ammunition is disassembled, and the morphological, dimensional, and compositional features of the bullet and cartridge case are examined. Statistical tests are employed to distinguish the dimensional differences between homemade and genuine ammunitions. Manufacturing marks on head stamps of the cartridge case are carefully examined. Compositional features of propellant powders, primer mixtures, and gunshot residues are also analyzed. The results reveal that the morphological, dimensional, and compositional features of major parts of the ammunition can be employed to differentiate homemade cartridges from genuine ones. Among these features, tool marks on the head stamps left by the bunter can be used to trace the origin of ammunition. © 2012 American Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Elemental analysis; Firearms examination; Forensic science; Gunshot residues; Homemade ammunition; Scanning electron microscopy/energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry

Title: The Use of Crimp Marks to Distinguish Between 357 SIG and 9mm Bullets
Authors with affiliations: Eric R. Collins, Deputy Sheriff-Criminalist, Office of the Sheriff, Contra Costa County, Forensic Services Division, Criminalistics Laboratory, Martinez, CA, USA
Author Keywords: The author was presented with a case involving a fired, deformed, nominal 38 caliber, full metal jacketed bullet as evidence. It was important to the facts of the case to determine whether the bullet was 9mm Luger or 357 SIG caliber. While most of the discernable class characteristics of the questioned bullet were very similar to commonly produced bullets of both calibers, it was determined that the position of the cartridge case crimp mark relative to the base of the bullet could be used as a discriminating factor to help determine which of the two types of cartridges it had been fired from. Due to the longer case length of 357 SIG cartridges compared to 9mm Luger cartridges and the similar overall length of both cartridges, the corresponding cartridge case crimp mark on 357 SIG bullets will be located farther from the base than those on 9mm bullets. The research conducted in this case is discussed within the framework of the scientific method.
Index Keywords: Bullet, cartridge case crimp mark, crimp groove, flat nose, FMJ, make and model determination, SAAMI, scientific method, truncated cone, 357 SIG, 9mm Luger, 9mm Parabellum, 9x19mm

Title: A Method for Reducing the Powder Charge of Rimfire Cartridges
Authors with affiliations: W. Kerkhoff and E.J.A.T. Mattijssen MSc, Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), The Hague, The Netherlands
Author Keywords: A method was developed to reduce the powder charge of rimfire cartridges, to be able to reduce muzzle velocity. The method proved to be practical and safe. After making and firing a series of cartridges with various reduced charges, it was possible to predict muzzle velocity within an approximate 30 m/s (98.4 ft/s) interval for any given powder charge, for that particular cartridge type. In this article the method is described and measurements for three series of cartridges with reduced charges are given as an example.
Index Keywords: Reducing powder charge, Reduced charge, Rimfire ammunition

Title: Unusual Black Polyethylene Shotshell Buffer material
Authors with affiliations: Technical Leader / Senior Forensic Scientist Michael S. Ward, Fort Worth Police Department Crime Laboratory, Firearms & Toolmark Unit, Fort Worth, Texas.
Author Keywords: With the increase in cost and demand for ammunition at the time of this paper, often lower quality products are the only option available for purchase and may perhaps begin to be more frequently encountered in casework. As the jacketing material on much of this ammunition is significantly thinner than what is more traditionally observed, it readily separates from the bullet core. Authors: Kumar J., Landheer D., Barnes-Warden J., Fenne P., Attridge A., Williams M.A.
Title: Inconsistency in 9 mm bullets measured with nondestructive X-ray computed tomography
Author Keywords: Fundamental to any ballistic armour standard is the reference projectile that is to be defeated. Typically, for certification, consistency of bullets is assumed. Therefore, practical variations in bullet jacket dimensions can have far reaching consequences. Traditionally, internal dimensions could only be analysed by cutting bullets which rules out any subsequent ballistic assessment. Therefore, the use of a non-destructive X-ray computed tomography (CT) method is explored in this paper. A set of 10 bullets (9 mm DM11) was taken for analysing both intra and inter bullet jacket thickness variation. CT measurements of jacket thickness were validated with high resolution scanning electron microscope (SEM) images. An image based analysis methodology has been developed to extract the jacket thickness map and the centre of gravity. Thickness variations of the order of 200 μm were found commonly across all the bullets along the length and an angular variation of up to 100 μm was found in a few bullets. Jacket thickness and centre of gravity were also calculated for the same bullets after impact and the variations between the pre- and post-impacted bullets were compared, by establishing a common physical reference. The results show that the proposed CT scanning approach and subsequent image analysis method can bring out the statistical variations in bullet geometry pre- and post impact effectively.
Index Keywords: X-ray computed tomography; Bullet geometry; Jacket thickness; Armour standards

Title: Air gun wounding and current UK laws controlling air weapons
Source title: Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine
Affiliations: Metropolitan Police, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bruce-Chwatt, R.M., Metropolitan Police, London, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: Air weapons whether rifles or pistols are, potentially, lethal weapons. The UK legislation is complex and yet little known to the public. Hunting with air weapons and the laws controlling those animals that are permitted to be shot with air weapons is even more labyrinthine due to the legal power limitations on the possession of air weapons. Still relatively freely available by mail order or on the Internet, an increasing number of deaths have been reported from the misuse of air weapons or accidental discharges. Ammunition for air weapons has become increasingly sophisticated, effective and therefore increasingly dangerous if misused, though freely available being a mere projectile without a concomitant cartridge containing a propellant and an initiator. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd and Faculty of Forensic and Legal Medicine.

Title: The Effect of the Legal Status of Blank Cartridge Firing Pistols on Their Use in Crime
Authors with affiliations: Aylin Yalcin Saribey, Ph.D., Ankara University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Engineering Physics, Tandogan, Ankara, 06100, Turkey; and Abigail Grace Hannam, M.Sc., Forensic Science Service, Firearms Department, London, UK
Author Keywords: Blank cartridge firing pistols have often been used in criminal offences in recent years. However, a significant problem has become apparent in Turkey concerning converted blank cartridge firing guns. The barrel obstruction can be removed and it is then possible to fire projectiles from these weapons with sufficient energy to cause lethal injuries. Since the emergence of this trend, the legislation concerning the manufacture and sale of blank cartridge firing guns has been changed and the 5729 Act was introduced. In this study; the effect of the new legislation on the use of blank cartridge firing guns in crimes and their forensic examination is discussed. It has been found that after the new Act was accepted in 2008 the number of converted and unconverted blank cartridge firing pistols which had been used in crime and subsequently examined in criminal laboratories had reduced. Once the new Act had been implemented in 2009, the numbers of converted and unconverted pistols used reduced further.
Index Keywords: forensic science, ballistics, blank pistol, modification, blank cartridge
