Authors: Taroni F., Bozza S., Biedermann A., Aitken C.
Title: Dismissal of the illusion of uncertainty in the assessment of a likelihood ratio
Affiliations: University of Lausanne, Faculty of Law, Criminal Justice and Public Administration, School of Criminal Justice, Lausanne-Dorigny, 1015, Switzerland; Ca' Foscari University of Venice, Department of Economics San Giobbe, Cannaregio 873, Venice, 30121, Italy; School of Mathematics, The King's Buildings, The University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, EH9 3JZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Taroni, F., University of Lausanne, Faculty of Law, Criminal Justice and Public Administration, School of Criminal Justice, Lausanne-Dorigny, 1015, Switzerland; Bozza, S., Ca' Foscari University of Venice, Department of Economics San Giobbe, Cannaregio 873, Venice, 30121, Italy; Biedermann, A., University of Lausanne, Faculty of Law, Criminal Justice and Public Administration, School of Criminal Justice, Lausanne-Dorigny, 1015, Switzerland; Aitken, C., School of Mathematics, The King's Buildings, The University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, EH9 3JZ, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: The use of the Bayes factor (BF) or likelihood ratio as a metric to assess the probative value of forensic traces is largely supported by operational standards and recommendations in different forensic disciplines. However, the progress towards more widespread consensus about foundational principles is still fragile as it raises new problems about which views differ. It is not uncommon e.g. to encounter scientists who feel the need to compute the probability distribution of a given expression of evidential value (i.e. a BF), or to place intervals or significance probabilities on such a quantity. The article here presents arguments to show that such views involve a misconception of principles and abuse of language. The conclusion of the discussion is that, in a given case at hand, forensic scientists ought to offer to a court of justice a given single value for the BF, rather than an expression based on a distribution over a range of values. © The Author [2015].
Index Keywords: Bayes factor; Estimation; Likelihood ratio; Probability; Uncertainty; Vari

Authors: Sjerps M.J., Alberink I., Bolck A., Stoel R.D., Vergeer P., Van Zanten J.H.
Title: Uncertainty and LR: To integrate or not to integrate, that's the question
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Korteweg-de Vries Institute for Mathematics, University of Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94248, GE Amsterdam, 1090, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Sjerps, M.J., Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands, Korteweg-de Vries Institute for Mathematics, University of Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94248, GE Amsterdam, 1090, Netherlands; Alberink, I., Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Bolck, A., Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Stoel, R.D., Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Vergeer, P., Netherlands Forensic Institute, P.O. Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Van Zanten, J.H., Korteweg-de Vries Institute for Mathematics, University of Amsterdam, P.O. Box 94248, GE Amsterdam, 1090, Netherlands
Author Keywords: Taroni et al. (2016) discuss the controversial issue of parameter uncertainty in the context of forensic evidence evaluation. Although we share with the authors the main idea that the likelihood ratio (LR) framework is the best method for evaluating forensic evidence, we have a different view on this issue. The core question is: does itmake sense to consider the uncertainty attached to a calculated value of the LR, and consequently, should we report a single value for the LR or in addition address its uncertainty? Taroni et al. (2016) argue for reporting a single value based on a 'full-Bayesian' approach, and accuse anyone who considers the uncertainty of an LR of 'misconception of basic principles' and 'abuse of language'. However, their arguments presented as facts or logic are in fact choices or opinions. Furthermore, reporting a single number for the LR deprives the legal justice system of essential information needed to assess the reliability of the evidence. Therefore, we argue that forensic scientists should not only report an LR value, but also address its uncertainty and we explain why this is not a misconception or abuse of language. © The Author [2015].
Index Keywords: Bayes factor; Estimation; Evidential value; Forensic science; Likelihood ratio; Reliability; Uncertainty

Authors: Dror I.E., Charlton D., Péron A.E.
Title: Contextual information renders experts vulnerable to making erroneous identifications
Affiliations: School of Psychology, Faculty of Medicine, Health and Life Sciences, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dror, I.E., School of Psychology, Faculty of Medicine, Health and Life Sciences, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Charlton, D., School of Psychology, Faculty of Medicine, Health and Life Sciences, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Péron, A.E., School of Psychology, Faculty of Medicine, Health and Life Sciences, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: We investigated whether experts can objectively focus on feature information in fingerprints without being misled by extraneous information, such as context. We took fingerprints that have previously been examined and assessed by latent print experts to make positive identification of suspects. Then we presented these same fingerprints again, to the same experts, but gave a context that suggested that they were a no-match, and hence the suspects could not be identified. Within this new context, most of the fingerprint experts made different judgements, thus contradicting their own previous identification decisions. Cognitive aspects involved in biometric identification can explain why experts are vulnerable to make erroneous identifications. © 2005 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.

Title: Meta-analytically quantifying the reliability and biasability of forensic experts
Affiliations: School of Psychology, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dror, I., School of Psychology, University of Southampton, Southampton SO17 1BJ, United Kingdom; Rosenthal, R., Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, United States
Author Keywords: In this paper we employ meta-analytic procedures and estimate effect sizes indexing the degree of reliability and biasability of forensic experts. The data are based on within-expert comparisons, whereby the same expert unknowingly makes judgments on the same data at different times. This allows us to take robust measurements and conduct analyses that compare variances within the same experts, and thus to carefully quantify the degree of consistency and objectivity that underlie expert performance and decision making. To achieve consistency, experts must be reliable, at least in the very basic sense that an expert makes the same decision when the same data are presented in the same circumstances, and thus be consistent with themselves. To achieve objectivity, experts must focus only on the data and ignore irrelevant information, and thus be unbiasable by extraneous context. The analyses show that experts are not totally reliable nor are they unbiasable. These findings are based on fingerprint experts decision making, but because this domain is so well established, they apply equally well (if not more) to all other less established forensic domains. © 2008 American Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Cognitive top-down processing; Confirmation bias; Fingerprint identification; Forensic decision making; Forensic science; Psychological influence; Reliability and biasability of expert decision making
Correspondence Address: article; decision making; forensic medicine; priority journal; reliability; task performance; Decision Making; Dermatoglyphics; Humans; Judgment; Professional Competence; Reproducibility of Results

Authors: Saks M.J., Risinger D.M., Rosenthal R., Thompson W.C.
Title: Context effects in forensic science: A review and application of the science of science to crime laboratory practice in the United States
Source title: Science and Justice - Journal of the Forensic Science Society
Affiliations: Department of Law and Psychology, Arizona State University, PO Box 877906, Tempe, AZ 85287-7906, United States; Seton Hall University School of Law, Newark, NJ, United States; Dept. of Criminol., Law and Society, University of California, Irvine, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saks, M.J., Department of Law and Psychology, Arizona State University, PO Box 877906, Tempe, AZ 85287-7906, United States; Risinger, D.M., Seton Hall University School of Law, Newark, NJ, United States; Rosenthal, R.; Thompson, W.C., Dept. of Criminol., Law and Society, University of California, Irvine, CA, United States
Author Keywords: This article discusses the phenomenon of "context effects" by reviewing the findings and practices of a range of scientific fields, including astronomy, physics, biology, medicine, and especially the relevant research and theory from psychology. Context information, such as expectations about what one is supposed to see or conclude, has been found to have a small but relentless impact on human perception, judgment, and decision-making. The article then considers the vulnerability of forensic science practice to context effects, and concludes by suggesting that forensic science adopt practices familiar in other fields of scientific work, in particular blind or double-blind testing and also the use of evidence line-ups. © The Forensic Science Society 2003.
Index Keywords: Bias; Blind testing; Context effects; Evidence line-ups; Expectancy effects; Experimenter effects; Forensic science; Observer effects

Title: Painting the target around the matching profile: The Texas sharpshooter fallacy in forensic DNA interpretation
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, W.C.
Author Keywords: Forensic DNA analysts tend to underestimate the frequency of matching profiles (and overestimate likelihood ratios) by shifting the purported criteria for a ‚Äòmatch‚Äô or ‚Äòinclusion‚Äô after the profile of a suspect becomes known‚Äîa process analogous to the well-known Texas sharpshooter fallacy. Using examples from casework, informal and naturalistic experiments, and analysts‚Äô own testimony, this article demonstrates how post hoc target shifting occurs and how it can distort the frequency and likelihood ratio statistics used to characterize DNA matches, making matches appear more probative than they actually are. It concludes by calling for broader adoption of more rigorous analytical procedures, such as sequential unmasking, that can reduce the sharpshooter fallacy by fixing the target before the shots are taken.
Index Keywords: DNA evidence; frequency; likelihood ratio; fallacy; sequential unmasking; DNA profile; bias; error; statistics; ACE-V.
Correspondence Address: NA

Title: What role should investigative facts play in the evaluation of scientific evidence?
Affiliations: University of California, Irvine, Dept. Criminology, Law Society, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, W.C., University of California, Irvine, Dept. Criminology, Law Society, United States
Author Keywords: Concern about contextual bias has led some authorities to recommend that forensic scientists know as little as possible about the facts of the underlying case when interpreting physical evidence; but concern about contextual ignorance has led other authorities to recommend, to the contrary, that forensic scientists know as much as possible in order to frame questions properly. This article recommends a case manager model that addresses both concerns. This article also responds to standard objections to the use of blind procedures in forensic science, explaining why contextual bias cannot be conquered through willpower; why use of domain-irrelevant contextual facts undermines the value of forensic evidence; how a well-known cognitive illusion (the 'introspection illusion') can mislead forensic scientists into thinking they can control their biases, when they cannot; and how a paradoxical feature of forensic inference (the 'criminalist's paradox') can mislead analysts into thinking they should rely on contextual facts, when they should not. © 2011 Australian Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: bias; blind procedures; case manager; context; domain-relevant; observer effect
Correspondence Address: article; DNA determination; epistemology; evidence based practice; forensic science; human; hybridization; illusion; introspection; methodology; observer bias

Title: Practical Solutions to Cognitive and Human Human Factor Challenges in Forensic Science
Source title: Forensic Science Policy & Management: An International Journal
Author Keywords: The growing understanding of the central role of human factors and cognition in forensic science has paved the way to develop and implement practical solutions to enhance work in forensic laboratories. Cognitive insights provide relatively simply practical solutions to minimize bias by increasing examiners’ independence of mind. These derive from understanding the spectrum of biases—not only those that can arise from knowing irrelevant case information, but also biases that emerge from base rate regularities, working ‘backwards’ from the suspect to the evidence, and from the working environment itself. Cognitive science’s contribution to forensic work goes beyond fighting bias, it suggests ways to enhance examiners’ work with technology (distributed cognition), as well as how best to select candidates during recruitment. Taking human cognition into account, such as with a triage approach and case managers, can enhance the quality and effectiveness of the work carried out by forensic examiners. This paper details practical solutions that emerge from a cognitive perspective that understand human expertise and performance. Such cognitively informed approaches should be integrated within forensic work on an ongoing basis.
Index Keywords: Confirmation bias; decision making; cognitive contamination; base-rate; technology; contextual influences; cognitive forensics; case managers; triage

Authors: Kassin S.M., Dror I.E., Kukucka J.
Title: The forensic confirmation bias: Problems, perspectives, and proposed solutions
Source title: Journal of Applied Research in Memory and Cognition
Affiliations: John Jay College of Criminal Justice, United States; University College London (UCL), United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kassin, S.M., John Jay College of Criminal Justice, United States; Dror, I.E., University College London (UCL), United Kingdom; Kukucka, J., John Jay College of Criminal Justice, United States
Author Keywords: As illustrated by the mistaken, high-profile fingerprint identification of Brandon Mayfield in the Madrid Bomber case, and consistent with a recent critique by the National Academy of Sciences (2009), it is clear that the forensic sciences are subject to contextual bias and fraught with error. In this article, we describe classic psychological research on primacy, expectancy effects, and observer effects, all of which indicate that context can taint people's perceptions, judgments, and behaviors. Then we describe recent studies indicating that confessions and other types of information can set into motion forensic confirmation biases that corrupt lay witness perceptions and memories as well as the judgments of experts in various domains of forensic science. Finally, we propose best practices that would reduce bias in the forensic laboratory as well as its influence in the courts. © 2013 Society for Applied Research in Memory and Cognition.
Index Keywords: Confirmation bias; Context effects; Expectancy effects

Authors: Mattijssen E.J.A.T., Kerkhoff W., Berger C.E.H., Dror I.E., Stoel R.D.
Title: Implementing context information management in forensic casework: Minimizing contextual bias in firearms examination
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute, PO Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Radboud University Nijmegen, Behavioural Science Institute, PO Box 9104, HE Nijmegen, 6500, Netherlands; Leiden University, Institute for Criminal Law and Criminology, PO Box 9520, RA Leiden, 2300, Netherlands; University College London (UCL) and Cognitive Consultants International (CCI-HQ), United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mattijssen, E.J.A.T., Netherlands Forensic Institute, PO Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands, Radboud University Nijmegen, Behavioural Science Institute, PO Box 9104, HE Nijmegen, 6500, Netherlands; Kerkhoff, W., Netherlands Forensic Institute, PO Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands; Berger, C.E.H., Netherlands Forensic Institute, PO Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands, Leiden University, Institute for Criminal Law and Criminology, PO Box 9520, RA Leiden, 2300, Netherlands; Dror, I.E., University College London (UCL) and Cognitive Consultants International (CCI-HQ), United Kingdom; Stoel, R.D., Netherlands Forensic Institute, PO Box 24044, AA The Hague, 2490, Netherlands
Author Keywords: Managing context information in forensic casework aims to minimize task-irrelevant information while maximizing the task-relevant information that reaches the examiner. A design and implementation of context information management (CIM) is described for forensic firearms examination. Guided by a taxonomy of different sources of context information, a flow-chart was constructed that specifies the process of casework examination and context information management. Due to the risk of bias, another examiner may need to be involved when context information management is unsuccessful. Application of context information management does not make a subjective examination objective, but can limit the risks of bias with a minimal investment of time and resources. © 2015 The Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Cognitive forensics; Context information management; Contextual bias; Quality assurance; Subjective judgment; Task-irrelevant case information
Correspondence Address: firearm; human; information system; investment; social worker; taxonomy

Authors: Stoel R., Berger C., Kerkhoff W., Mattijssen E. J. A. T., Dror I.
Title: Minimizing Contextual Bias in Forensic Casework
Source title: In Forensic Science and the Administration of Justice: Critical Issues and Directions, K. J. Strom & M. J. Hickman, eds., SAGE Publications, Inc.

Authors: Mattijssen E.J.A.T., Stoel R.D., Kerkhoff W.
Title: Minimizing Contextual Bias in Forensic Firearms Examination
Source title: In book: Wiley Encyclopedia of Forensic Science
Author Keywords: Solutions to cognitive and human factor challenges in forensic science are emerging [Dror, I.E. (2014). Practical solutions to cognitive and human factor challenges in forensic science, Forensic Science Policy & Management 4(3–4), 1–9.], but have not yet been widely communicated let alone applied in practice. Within the discipline of forensic firearms examination, a procedure has been developed and implemented that minimizes the effects of domain-irrelevant information and maximizes the utilization of domain-relevant information. This procedure, termed context management, is described and for this we distinguish between different types of contextual information that an examiner may come across. Contextual information may come from the trace (Level 1), the reference material (Level 2), the case information (Level 3), and the “base rate” information (Level 4) [Stoel, R., Berger, C., Kerkhoff, W., Mattijssen, E.J.A.T. & Dror, I. (2014). Minimizing Contextual Bias in Forensic Casework, in Forensic Science and the Administration of Justice: Critical Issues and Directions, p. 67–86, SAGE.]. By going through the steps of the examination of a typical comparison case (i.e., checking and acceptance of the case, preassessment of the case, comparison of the markings, and peer review and reporting), it is illustrated how and when contextual information may influence the examiners' judgment and how this influence can be minimized by implementing context management.
Index Keywords: context management; contextual bias; domain irrelevant; case information; subjective judgment; quality assurance; firearms

Authors: Mikko D., Miller J., Flater J.
Title: Reproducibility of Toolmarks on 20,000 Bullets fired through an M240 Machine Gun Barrel
Authors with affiliations: Don Mikko, Jerry Miller and Jason Flater, United States Army Criminal Investigation Laboratory (USACIL), 4930 N 31st Street, Forest Park, GA 30297, USA
Author Keywords: This article discusses the reproducibility of toolmarks on 7.62mm high velocity bullets fired through a single M240 machine gun barrel. Over the years, there have been several research studies and published articles pertaining to consecutively manufactured rifled barrels and the ability to microscopically identify bullets as having been fired through the same barrel of a firearm; however, to the knowledge of the authors, there has not been any in-depth microscopic study pertaining to 20,000 bullets being fired through a single rifled barrel and subsequently identified to that particular barrel. Based on the recent findings as stated in the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) Report, this article should provide credible evidence in regards to the reproducibility and uniqueness of striations on the bearing surfaces of fired bullets.
Index Keywords: M240 Machine gun, 7.62x51mm NATO cartridge, reproducibility, bullets

Title: An empirical study/validation test pertaining to the reproducibility of toolmarks on 20,000 bullets fired through M240 machine gun barrels
Affiliations: Atlanta Police Department Crime Laboratory, 180 Southside Industrial Parkway, Atlanta, GA, 30354, United States; ATF Atlanta Forensic Science Laboratory, 2600 Century Parkway, NE, Suite 400, Atlanta, GA, 30345, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mikko, D., Atlanta Police Department Crime Laboratory, 180 Southside Industrial Parkway, Atlanta, GA, 30354, United States; Miller, J., ATF Atlanta Forensic Science Laboratory, 2600 Century Parkway, NE, Suite 400, Atlanta, GA, 30345, United States
Author Keywords: This article is a follow-up to an article that was published in the AFTE Journal-Volume 44, Number 3-Summer 2012, titled Reproducibility of Toolmarks on 20,000 Bullets fired through an M240 Machine Gun Barrel [1]. Using a second M240 Machine gun with its original barrel, along with a new spare barrel assembly, thirty (30) additional bullets were test fired through both barrels and subsequently inter-compared blindly by four firearm and toolmark examiners, one of which had just completed his formal two-year training period. Additionally, the recovered (60) test fired bullets from both barrels were also mixed with the 127 bullets recovered during the test firing of 20,000 bullets in the reproducibility study and examined by the four firearm and toolmark examiners in a blind test study, in order to determine whether or not the examiners could correctly identify or eliminate the bullets as being fired through the correct barrel.
Index Keywords: Error rate; Identification; M240 Machine gun; National Academy of Sciences (NAS); Reproducibility

Title: The inter-comparison of 1,000 consecutively-fired 9mm luger bullets and cartridge cases from a ruger p89 pistol utilizing both pattern matching and quantitative consecutive matching striae as criteria for identification
Affiliations: Alameda County Sheriff's Office Crime Laboratory, San Leandro, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wong, C., Alameda County Sheriff's Office Crime Laboratory, San Leandro, CA, United States
Author Keywords: Previous studies have investigated the effect of consecutive firing of firearms to determine how the wear on barrels and breechfaces would affect the identification of fired bullets and cartridge cases. This study was conducted to determine if the toolmarks on fired bullets and cartridge cases would change significantly after firing 1,000 cartridges through a Ruger P89 9mm Luger semiautomatic pistol, while using both pattern matching and quantitative consecutively matching striae (QCMS) as identification criteria during the comparison process. While there were some differences between the toolmarks on the bullets and cartridge cases throughout the firing sequence, each bullet and cartridge case was successfully identified to the first bullet or cartridge case.
Index Keywords: Consecutive firing; Consecutive matching striae (CMS); Criteria for identification; Firing pin aperture shear marks; Longevity study; Persistence of toolmarks; Quantitative consecutive matching striae (QCMS)

Authors: Yong J.B., Wun C.T., Kuppuswamy R.
Title: Further Investigations into the Permanence of Breechface Recess and Other Marks on Cartridge Cases Discharged from 9mm Calibre Walther P99 Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Jee Boon Yong, Ch'ng Tze Wun, R. Kuppuswamy, Forensic Science Programme, School of Health Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Kampus Kesihatan, 16150 Kubang Kerian, Kelantan, Malaysia
Author Keywords: This report describes the permanence of the toolmarks on cartridge cases discharged from 9 mm calibre Walther P99 pistols. Three weapons that were subjected to extensive firing in the years 2010 and 2012 were used for the study. The cartridge cases expended from the firearms in these two years were examined in order to verify whether the marks on them have been persistent. Results have shown that breechface recess marks, firing pin impression and firing pin aperture shear marks showed reproducibility. In addition, all the marks above except the breechface impression held sufficient individual characteristics for identification. Thus, the identity of the weapon from the expended cartridge cases from Walther P99 pistols after extensive firing could be determined. Significantly, the breechface recess marks presented themselves in all the three weapons as useful for comparison.
Index Keywords: breechface, breechface recess, persistence of characteristics, class characteristics, individual characteristics, firing pin impression, firing pin aperture shear, Walther P99

Authors: Fadul Jr. T.G., Hernandez G.A., Stoiloff S., Gulat S.
Title: An empirical study to improve the scientific foundation of forensic firearm and tool mark identification utilizing 10 consecutively manufactured slides
Affiliations: Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory, Miami, FL, United States; Department of Statistics, Florida International University, Miami, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fadul Jr., T.G., Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory, Miami, FL, United States; Hernandez, G.A., Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory, Miami, FL, United States; Stoiloff, S., Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory, Miami, FL, United States; Gulat, S., Department of Statistics, Florida International University, Miami, FL, United States
Author Keywords: The Miami-Dade Police Department Crime Laboratory conducted a research study on The Repeatability and Uniqueness of Striations/Impressions on Fired Cartridge Casings Fired in 10 Consecutively Manufactured 9mm Ruger Slides to improve understanding of the accuracy, reliability, and measurement validity in the firearm and tool mark discipline of forensic science. The foundation of firearm and tool mark identification is that each firearm/tool produces a signature of identification (striation/impression) that is unique to that firearm/tool, and through the examination of the individual striations/impressions, the signature can be positively identified to the firearm/tool that produced it. The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) Report questioned the repeatability and uniqueness of striations/impressions left on fired evidence as well as the validity and error rate in firearms identification. This study analyzed the repeatability and uniqueness of striations/impressions on fired cartridge cases fired in 10 consecutively manufactured Ruger slides by analyzing breech face striations/impressions through an evaluation of the participants' accuracy in making correct identifications. One semi-automatic pistol and nine additional consecutively manufactured slides were utilized. Consecutively manufactured slides are significant to this study because they were manufactured with the same equipment/tools. Even though these slides were consecutively made, their signatures should be different. Test sets assembled included test fired casings from each slide, as well as unknowns. Participants were firearm & tool mark examiners throughout the United States. One hundred and fifty-eight test sets were distributed to laboratories in forty-six states and the District of Columbia. The test sets were designed to determine an examiner's ability to correctly identify cartridge casings fired from 10 consecutively manufactured Ruger Slides to test fired cartridge casings fired from the same slides. This empirical study established an error rate of less than 0.1 percent. Durability testing established that the Ruger Slides maintained their individual signature after multiple firings. This project was supported by Award No. 2009-DN-BX-K230 awarded by the National Institute of Justice, Office of Justice Programs, U. S. Department of Justice. The opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this publication/program/exhibition are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect those of the Department of Justice.
Index Keywords: Breechface; Cartridge cases; Consecutive manufacture; Error rate; NAS; Ruger slides; Validity

Authors: Yalçin Saribey A., Grace Hannam A.
Title: Comparison of the Class and Individual Characteristics of Turkish 7.65mm Browning/.32 Automatic Caliber Self-Loading Pistols with Consecutive Serial Numbers
Affiliations: Ankara University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Engineering Physics, Tandoǧan 06100, Turkey; Forensic Science Service, Firearms Department, 109 Lambeth Road, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Yalçin Saribey, A., Ankara University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Engineering Physics, Tandoǧan 06100, Turkey; Grace Hannam, A., Forensic Science Service, Firearms Department, 109 Lambeth Road, London, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: Firearms identification is based on the fundamental principle that it is impossible to manufacture two identical items at the microscopic level. As firearm manufacturing technologies and quality assurance are improving, it is necessary to continually challenge this principle. In this study, two different makes of 7.65mm Browning/.32 Automatic caliber self-loading pistols of Turkish manufacture were selected and examined. Ten pistols with consecutive serial numbers were examined and each fired 10 times. The fired cartridge cases were recovered for comparison purposes. It was found that for each make of pistol, the individual characteristics within the firing pin impression, ejector, and breech face marks of all 10 pistols were found to be significantly different. © 2012 American Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Class characteristics; Comparison; Firearms identification; Forensic science; Individual characteristics; Pistol

Title: An evaluation of the individuality of the two types of remington 870 Extractors-Metal injection molded vs. Milled
Affiliations: Onondaga County Center for Forensic Sciences, Syracuse, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berghorn, S., Onondaga County Center for Forensic Sciences, Syracuse, NY, United States
Author Keywords: Remington 870 shotguns possess different types of extractors depending on whether it is a commercial or law enforcement variant. The commercial 870 shotguns are equipped with a metal injection molded extractor whereas the law enforcement versions have a milled extractor. Six extractors of each type were examined and compared to determine if there was any carryover of class or individual markings within a type or between the two types. Although some similarities existed between each extractor within each type, each extractor was still able to be differentiated from one another and the extractor marks were all able to he identified back to their corresponding extractor. © 2014, Association of Firearm and Tool Mark Examiners.
Index Keywords: Extractor; Metal injection molding; Milled; MIM; Remington 870

Title: Metal injection molded strikers and extractors in a Smith & Wesson model M&P pistol
Affiliations: Monroe County Crime Laboratory, Firearms and Toolmark Section, Rochester, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hunsinger, M., Monroe County Crime Laboratory, Firearms and Toolmark Section, Rochester, NY, United States
Author Keywords: During the summer of 2009, Smith & Wesson (S&W) began selling their M&P model pistols with metal injection molded (MIM) strikers. Currently, all calibers except the .45 use such strikers, but all M&P pistols contain MIM manufactured extractors. Five MIM strikers and extractors were obtained from S&W. Firing pin impressions, firing pin drag marks and extractor marks were used to compare class and individual characteristics within these markings, to assess the potential of subclass characteristics, as well as the durability of the working surfaces.
Index Keywords: Electropolishing; Extractor; Firing pin impression; Metal injection molding; MIM; Smith and Wesson model M and P; Striker

Title: Metal Injection Molded Breech Face of a Taurus Revolver
Author Keywords: A .357 Magnum caliber Taurus revolver was submitted to the laboratory along with a fired cartridge case. The revolver’s pebbled breech face raised the question -- was this particular surface unique or was it was another example of class or subclass characteristics? Information from Taurus regarding the manufacturing processes indicated that the characteristics were not subclass.
Index Keywords: bead blasting, breech face, casting, individual characteristics, MIM, metal injection molding, subclass characteristics

Title: The effect of vibratory finishing on broaching marks as a function of time
Affiliations: MS California DOJ BFS Fresno Regional Crime Laboratory, Fresno, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Winn, J.A., MS California DOJ BFS Fresno Regional Crime Laboratory, Fresno, CA, United States
Author Keywords: Previous research has focused primarily on the impact of primary machining processes (i.e. broaching, milling, grinding) on individual and subclass characteristics with speculation as to the impact of the finishing processes. As a result, research on the impact of finishing processes after machining on subclass and individual characteristics needed to be done. Based on the information gathered through research and during firearm manufacturer tours, broaching was used as the primary machining process and the effect of vibratory finishing on broaching marks as a function of time was examined. Vibratory finishing as a function of time did have a significant impact upon the individual markings caused by broaching. The finer, individual stria were removed as finishing time increased causing the grosser, individual marks to appear more pronounced. Subclass characteristics would then also appear more pronounced. An identification between different finishing times could be made; however, this research demonstrates that the firearms and toolmark examiner may need to consider the finishing method when identifications are being made.
Index Keywords: Broaching; Finishing processes; Individual; Machining processes; Subclass; Vibratory finishing

Authors: O'Keeffe C., Champion S., Allsop D.
Title: Demonstrating the effect of forensic firearm countermeasures: Bullet characteristics generated due to barrel modifications
Affiliations: Cranfield Forensic Institute, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom; Centre for Defence Engineering, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: O'Keeffe, C., Cranfield Forensic Institute, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom; Champion, S., Centre for Defence Engineering, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom; Allsop, D., Cranfield Forensic Institute, Cranfield University, Defence Academy of the United Kingdom, Shrivenham, SN6 8LA, United Kingdom
Author Keywords: Forensic awareness and the declining availability of firearms have resulted in an increase in the use of modified and re-activated firearms in crime. Although some modifications are undertaken to simply acquire a functioning firearm, others are perpetrated as a direct forensic countermeasure to prevent the association between a firearm and a crime. This article describes the effects of these modifications on bullet striation patterns imparted from the barrel to a fired bullet. The key results indicated that the investigated modifications display assessable characteristics. The use of an oversized barrel imparted striations consistent with firing with the absence of typical rifling. Subsequent or consecutively fired bullets possessed striation variations, with the first showing the least evidence of striations. The application of a choke resulted in more obvious bullet elongation compared to a smoothbore barrel. The restriction caused merging of lands and groves of the imparted rifling and obscured their usual definition. Effects of breech adaption were also characterised by observing the buckling and enlargement of the cartridge case. This deformity of the cartridge case was most evident when the barrel pressure increased due to the presence of the choke. From this study it was evident that unique characteristic impressions associated with different modifications most commonly found in criminal investigations can be utilised by a forensic expert and impart significant intelligence to an investigation. © 2015 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
Index Keywords: Barrel modifications; Bullet striations; Forensic countermeasures
Correspondence Address: awareness; ballistics; bullet; crime; firearm; forensic identification; microscopy; pressure; priority journal; Review; safety; velocity

Title: Determining the Identifiability of the Winchester PDX1 410 Defender Shotshell Components to the Taurus Judge Revolver
Authors with affiliations: Grant D. Lee, Montgomery County Police Department, Forensic Services Section, Rockville, Maryland
Author Keywords: Due to increasing sales of the Winchester PDX1 410 Defender shotshells, attributable in part to heightened public interest in home defense, it is likely that an examiner could encounter cases involving this type of ammunition and be asked to provide an analysis of the identifiability of this type of ammunition, the components thereof, and possibly to also identify the firearm from which it was fired. It is shown that reproducible individual markings imparted by the firearm can be found on this type of ammunition, or its components, through microscopic examination.
Index Keywords: identifiability, multi-caliber revolvers, PDX1 410 Defender, Taurus Judge, wad, wadding, Winchester

Title: The effects of frangible ammunition on the structure of striae created by a rifled barrel and the value of frangible ammunition for examination
Affiliations: Scottsdale Police Department Crime Laboratory, Scottsdale, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Raines, M.E., Scottsdale Police Department Crime Laboratory, Scottsdale, AZ, United States
Author Keywords: Frangible ammunition is used in many indoor law enforcement ranges for training purposes. The concept of frangible ammunition is that it is designed to break up into non-hazardous fragments on impact with a metal target and has the benefits of being lead free, creating a safer and more easily maintained training environment. The purpose of this research project was a twofold evaluation of contemporary frangible ammunition. First, a study was conducted to determine the effects, if any, frangible ammunition had on the rifling characteristics of a gun barrel. Secondly, frangible ammunition was recovered after being fired at several target materials to determine if the fractured pieces were of any value for examination. The use of the frangible ammunition changed the working surface of the barret of one of the evaluated firearms such that the striae were altered. Surprisingly, intact and potentially identifiable frangible bullets were recovered after being fired through the target materials. © 2015, AFTF Journal. All Rights Reserved.
Index Keywords: Fouling; Frangible ammunition; Tinning

Title: Identification of pierced primers of.45 GAP ammunition fired in.45 ACP firearms
Affiliations: Firearm/Toolmark Unit, Michigan Stale Police, Lansing, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, M., Firearm/Toolmark Unit, Michigan Stale Police, Lansing, MI, United States
Author Keywords: The purpose of this research was to determine if .45 CAP caliber ammunition would tend to experience pierced primers when fired in.45 ACP caliber pistols. If so, could those Jired. 45 GA P cartridge cases be identified to fired.45 A CP curt ridge cases which were fired in the same pistols? In this research,.45 GAP ammunition was fired in ten different makes and models of.45 ACP caliber pistols, and the fired cartridge cases were retained for examination and comparison purposes. Testing revealed that.45 ACP pistols firing.45 GAP ammunition experienced numerous malfunctions, that the fired.45 GAP primers possessed a high tendency to pierce, and that the fired.45 GAP fired cartridge cases could be identified - or had the potential to be identified - to the particular.45 A CP pistol from which they were fired. © 2015, AFTF Journal. All Rights Reserved.
Index Keywords: 45 ACP; 45 GAP; Carbon; Cartridge mismatch; Comparisons; Ealiber mismatch; Large pistol primer; Malfunctions; Pierced primers; Small pistol primer

Title: The restoration of rusted firearms: An evaluation of different methods
Affiliations: Salt Lake City Police Department Crime Laboratory, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mears, D., Salt Lake City Police Department Crime Laboratory, Salt Lake City, UT, United States
Author Keywords: A survey conducted of a number of firearms sections indicated that when presented with a rusted firearm, different firearms sections are using different practices. In this paper a number of different methods of rust removal and restoration of firearms are examined. Each method is evaluated for its effectiveness with regard to removing rust and restoring the working surfaces of the firearm, specifically the bore and breechface, so that individual characteristics are recovered and preserved. The comparisons of test fired bullets and cartridge cases collected prior to the firearm rusting and collected following restoration of the firearm, as well as the effects of fresh versus salt water are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Break-Free CLP®; Corrosion; Electrolytic; Oxidation; Rust; Rust Release™; Soda blasting; Ultrasonic

Title: Reprint: Forensic Ballistics
Authors with affiliations: Goddard, C.H.M.
Author Keywords: This reprint of "Forensic Ballistics" was first published in 1925 in "Army Ordnance" Volume VI, No. 33. This article is being reprinted with permission from the U.S. Army Ordnance Corps Association (USAOCA), formerly the Army Ordnance Association, and was submitted by AFTE Member James Roberts. The following was written in the "Who's Mho in this Issue" portion. "Maj. Calvin H. Goddard, Ord. Res., in his paper, "Forensic Ballistics, " describes one of the most interesting practical applications of ordnance technique developed in recent years. We feel certain that those of our readers who are particularly interested in small arms, their history' and development, Will find in the researches described by Major Goddard a very-practical and scientific solution of a problem which has confused and often times frustrated our foremost criminologists. We feel particularly grateful to Major Goddard and his associates for the privilege of publishing his paper since this is the first formal presentation of these data in American literature. ".

Title: Unintentional altering of firing pins in top break (hinged frame) firearms
Affiliations: Punjab Forensic Science Agency (PFSA), Lahore, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Yasin, M.I., Punjab Forensic Science Agency (PFSA), Lahore, Pakistan
Author Keywords: In top break (hinged frame) firearms, if the spring controlling the movement of a firing pin is absent, damaged or, due to some other reason, has lost its control over the firing pin, the firing pin will move freely. In such cases the firing pin is often altered during opening and closing of the action of the firearm. Therefore in such firearms the firing pin impression on fired cartridge/shotshell cases is changed over time. These changed firing pin impressions may deceive an examiner during an examination. Despite these changed firing pin impressions, the identification can be made through careful examination of breech face marks. The information provided in this paper will be useful for the firearm examiners when comparing the cartridge/shotshell cases fired in the top break hinged frame firearms having free moving firing pins.
Index Keywords: Altered firing Pin; Firing pin impression; Hinged frame; Identification; Top break; Unintentional altering

Title: A Case Study of the Interpretation of Extraordinary Toolmarks on a Fatal Bullet
Authors with affiliations: Sergeant Gerard Dutton, Ballistics Section, Tasmania Police, Hobart, AUSTRALIA
Author Keywords: Whilst the available forensic firearms evidence in any shooting murder is usually important to the case and assists in the reconstruction of events, only occasionally does it become the single most important aspect of the investigation and subsequent trial. This case study is one of those instances and was a technically challenging forensic firearms investigation from a number of perspectives. The firearms evidence was key to understanding what had occurred, primarily hinging on the interpretation of various toolmarks left on a .22 calibre fatal bullet. The toolmarks included those left by the bore but more importantly also comprised three other extraordinary marks, all occurring by totally separate processes during loading by the use of an aftermarket magazine in conjunction with the exhibit sawn off rifle. This article focuses mainly on the interpretation of these marks, how the marks were inter-related and the philosophy of identification. For completeness, the case study also includes a discussion of other important associated aspects of the forensic firearms evidence.
Index Keywords: Butler Creek Magazine, Chamber mouth marks, Impressions, Ruger 10/22 rifle, Toolmarks

Authors: Ghani N.I.M., Malek M.F.A., Harun R., Kuppuswamy R.
Title: Breechface Recess Marks Recorded on Cart ridge Cases Expended from Beretta Px4 Storm Subcompact 9mm Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Nurul Izwani Mohamad Ghani1, Mohd Fazli Abd Malek1 , Rasyidi Harun2, R. Kuppuswamy 1 1Forensic Science Programme, School of Health Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Kampus Kesihatan, 16150 Kubang Kerian, Kelantan, Malaysia 2Armourment Division, Logisti
Author Keywords: The breechface recess marks noticed on expended cartridge cases fired from Beretta Px4 Storm Subcompact 9mm pistols are presented. The cartridge cases discharged from twenty numbers of the above pistol were examined under a comparison microscope (Leica FS C, x60) for the characteristics of the marks. The marks appeared across the rim of the cartridge cases and possessed identifiable characteristics in some of the guns; while in others they were less reproducible leading to inconclusive results. The marks generated between cartridge cases have been generally distorted and hence needed a careful examination and evaluation.
Index Keywords: Beretta Px4 Storm Subcompact 9mm pistols, Breechface Recess Marks, Firearms Identification

Title: Feed Ramp Marks Produced from a Ruger model LCP
Authors with affiliations: Stacey Hartman, Indiana State Police, Fort Wayne, Indiana
Author Keywords: Reproducible cycling marks due to contact with the feed ramp and frame may be found on the nose of a cartridge cycled or bullet fired in a Ruger model LCP pistol.
Index Keywords: Bullet Nose, Cycling, Feed Ramp, Impressions, LCP, Ruger, Striations

Title: Chamber Marks Preserved in a Badly Corroded Firearm
Authors with affiliations: Kevin M. Streine, New Mexico Department of Public Safety Headquarters Crime Laboratory, Santa Fe, New Mexico USA
Author Keywords: An identification was made between fired cartridge cases found at the scene of a triple homicide and a Cobray/SWD brand firearm. The firearm was recovered from a chemical toilet and was badly corroded. A live cartridge that was found in the chamber of the firearm likely helped to preserve the chamber marks used to make the identification.

Affiliations: Punjab Forensic Science Agency (PFSA), Lahore, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Yasin, M.I., Punjab Forensic Science Agency (PFSA), Lahore, Pakistan
Author Keywords: While comparing test fired cartridge cases and fired cases from a crime scene, unusual marks were observed on test fired cases. It was determined unusual marks on the test fired cartridge cases were due to tampering of the bolt face, extractor and ejector of the firearm; an obvious attempt by the criminal to avoid firearm identification.

Affiliations: Indiana State Police, Lowell, IN, United States

Author Keywords: A Baford Arms, Model Thunder, 410 bore Derringer was submitted to the Indiana State Police Laboratory in a Homicide Investigation. The case involved a firearm that was recovered in Nevada after the suspect fled Indiana. A rifled slug was recovered from the victim's body in Indiana. A comparison of the rifled slug to the questioned firearm was conducted.

Title: GLOCK versus SMITH & WESSON MODEL SW40F: Comparison of Markings on Fired Cartridge Cases
Authors with affiliations: Ronald G. Nichols, Criminalist, Oakland Police Department Criminalistics Laboratory, Oakland, CA, USA
Author Keywords: Prior to the introduction of Smith & Wesson's Sigma Series, Model SW40F, semi-automatic pistol, cartridge cases fired in Glock pistols were readily recognized by the rectangular firing pin impression and the striated shear marks above and below the impression. Smith & Wesson's newest addition to the firearms market the SW40F, is very similar in design to the Glock. Cartridge cases fired in this Smith & Wesson pistol have firing pin impressions and shear marks very similar to those of the Glock. This article discusses other firearm produced markings that may allow an examiner to distinguish between cartridge cases fired in a Glock and a Smith & Wesson SW40F.
Index Keywords: Glock, Smith & Wesson, 40 S&W, fired cases

Title: Fired Cartridge Case Comparisons: 9mm and .40 Caliber Glock vs. Smith and Wesson Sigma Series Pistols
Authors with affiliations: By: Nancy D. McCombs, California State Department of Justice, Fresno, CA
Author Keywords: In 1994 and 1995, Smith and Wesson introduced the Model SW40F and SW9F Sigma Series pistols which exhibit similar class characteristics on fired cartridge cases to those fired in Glock pistols. Consequently, in the absence of bullets the firearm examiner can no longer list the Glock pistol as the sole suspect firearm when considering the class characteristics of fired cartridge cases. Due to the infrequent number of Sigma Series pistols in circulation, earlier comparisons of fired cartridge cases from the two types of pistols were limited. In this study, similarities and differences in class characteristics are compared between cartridgecases fired from a considerable number of 9mm and .40 caliber Glock and Smith and Wesson Sigma Series pistols.
Index Keywords: Cartridge Case, Glock, Smith and Wesson, Sigma Series Pistols

Authors: Schecter B., Siso R., Giverts P., Hocherman G.
Title: Underside Ejector Marks From Glock Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Bernie Schecter, Rafi Siso, Pavel Giverts and Gil Hocherman, Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel Police National HQ, Jerusalem.
Author Keywords: Two types of pistols - Glock and S&W Sigma are very easily confused in attempted identifications via their expended cartridge cases. We have found a definitive difference between the two types of pistols via the underside ejector mark present on cartridge cases discharged in Glock pistols and absent on cartridge cases from S&W Sigma pistols. Testing of various models and calibers of both Glock and Sigma pistols has been undertaken to verify this.
Index Keywords: Glock, Smith & Wesson, Sigma, ejector, cartridge case

Title: Breechface Recess Marks Produced by Glock and Smith & Wesson Sigma Series Pistols
Authors with affiliations: Charles M. Clow, Tarrant County Medical Examiner's Office, Fort Worth, TX
Author Keywords: Reproducible cycling marks found on the rim of cartridge cases from Glock and Smith & Wesson Sigma Series pistols were found to be produced as the cartridge is released from the magazine lips and strikes the left underside corner of the of breechface recess.
Index Keywords: Glock, Smith & Wesson, Sigma, cycling marks, breechface recess

Authors: Bokobza L., Giverts P., Siso R.
Title: Into the breech once again - family characteristic differences between Glock and smith and Wesson Pistols
Affiliations: Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bokobza, L., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Giverts, P., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Siso, R., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Several recently published papers have discussed family characteristics of Glock and Smith and Wesson Sigma pistols, describing how examiners can differentiate between them and in some cases which model discharged and ejected specific cartridge cases. Author Keywords: This article will discuss a characteristic marking found on cartridge cases discharged from Czechoslovakian CZ model S3 caliber 380 Auto pistols. Authors: Bokobza L., Zidon Y., Tordjman D.
Title: Class characteristic markings on cartridges fired from homemade submachine guns
Affiliations: Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bokobza, L., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Zidon, Y., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Tordjman, D., Firearms Identification Laboratory, Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Homemade Submachine Guns (HSMG) have been received in our laboratory during the past several years. Two HSMGs were examined and named Type / and Type II. The intention of this research is to investigate and present the similar and the different class characteristics of HSMGs against conventional SMGs (Carl Gustav/Port Said and UZI). The ability of the IBIS® system to distinguish between homemade and original manufactured SMG was studied. © 2014, Association of Firearm and Tool Mark Examiners.

Title: Subclass characteristics in a Gamo air rifle barrel
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), The Hague, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Mattijssen, E.J.A.T., Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), The Hague, Netherlands; Kerkhoff, W., Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI), The Hague, Netherlands
Author Keywords: In recent casework a Gamo, caliber .22 air rifle was received, showing subclass characteristics in its barrel. A high degree of correspondence was found between striations present in the different lands of the same barrel.
Index Keywords: Air rifle; Barrel; Gamo; Land engraved areas; Subclass characteristics

Title: Breech face subclass characteristics of the Jimenez JA Nine pistol
Affiliations: Kansas Bureau of Investigation, Firearm and Toolmark Section, Topeka, KS, United States
Authors with affiliations: Welch, A.K., Kansas Bureau of Investigation, Firearm and Toolmark Section, Topeka, KS, United States
Author Keywords: During the course of casework and review of IBIS correlation results, potential subclass characteristics were observed within breech face marks on cartridge cases fired in Jimenez Arms JA Nine pistols. The purpose of the research was two-fold, first, determine the source of the mark and secondly determine if the mark could be attributed to a particular range of production dates. Through the examination of multiple firearms, breech face casts, and test fired specimens, the presence of subclass characteristics was confirmed. Manufacturing information was obtained to understand the complete manufacturing process and to determine the source of the subclass mark. Direct observation of the manufacturing process was received as well as obtaining and examining consecutively manufactured slides.
Index Keywords: Bolt insert; Breech face; Consecutively manufactured; Die casting; JA Nine; Jimenez arms; Spot facing; Subclass characteristics

Authors: Pauw-Vugts P., Walters A., Øren L., Pfoser L.
Title: FAID 2009: Proficiency Test and Workshop
Authors with affiliations: Petra Pauw-Vugts, Netherlands Forensic Institute, The Hague, The Netherlands; Alice Walters, Metropolitan Police Service, London, United Kingdom; Leif Oren, Kripos, Oslo, Norway; Leopold Pfoser, Bundeskriminalamt, Wiesbaden, Germany
Author Keywords: A Firearms Identification proficiency test and follow-up workshop was arranged in 2009/2010 within the framework of the ENFSI (European Network of Forensic Science Institutes) Expert Working Group Firearms/GSR. The proficiency test was called FAID2009 (FireArms IDentification 2009). The test consisted of ten sets of samples, five with bullets and five with cartridge cases. Each set consisted of three items: one unknown item and two items from a known firearm. In five of the test sets, the unknown and the known items were from different firearms. All the items for each test set were polymer castings from the same original fired bullets and cartridge cases. In this way, all the examiners from the different laboratories were given the opportunity to examine identical marks. The test sets were sent to 68 forensic laboratories (table 1), mostly in Europe (61), and examiners were asked to compare the unknown item in each test set with the known items, and choose a conclusion from a virtual scale with 5 (+1 ) levels ranging from identification to exclusion / elimination, with a level available for "unsuitable". Sixty-four laboratories returned the answer form, and 637 conclusions were given. Twenty-six conclusions (4%) were false identifications and thirteen conclusions (2%) were false exclusions. Forty-three of the laboratories attended the follow-up workshop, where the results were discussed.
Index Keywords: false exclusions, false identifications, proficiency test, subclass characteristics, FAID2005, FAID2009

Authors: Kerkhoff W., Stoel R.D., Berger C.E.H., Mattijssen E.J.A.T., Hermsen R., Smits N., Hardy H.J.J.
Title: Design and results of an exploratory double blind testing program in firearms examination
Affiliations: Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands; VU University Amsterdam, VUA, Amsterdam, Netherlands; University of Amsterdam, UvA, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Leiden University, Leiden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kerkhoff, W., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands; Stoel, R.D., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands; Berger, C.E.H., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands, Leiden University, Leiden, Netherlands; Mattijssen, E.J.A.T., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands; Hermsen, R., Netherlands Forensic Institute, Netherlands Forensic Institute, NFI, The Hague, Netherlands; Smits, N., VU University Amsterdam, VUA, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Hardy, H.J.J., University of Amsterdam, UvA, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Author Keywords: In 2010, the Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA) started a series of tests for the NFI's Firearms Section. Ten cartridge case and bullet comparison tests were submitted by various external parties as regular cases and mixed in the flow of real cases. The results of the tests were evaluated with the VU University Amsterdam (VUA). A total of twenty-nine conclusions were drawn in the ten tests. For nineteen conclusions the submitted cartridge cases or bullets were either fired from the questioned firearm or from one and the same firearm, in tests where no firearm was submitted. For ten conclusions the submitted cartridge cases or bullets were either fired from another firearm than the submitted one or from several firearms, in tests where no firearm was submitted. In none of the conclusions misleading evidence was reported, in the sense that all conclusions supported the true hypothesis. This article discusses the design considerations of the program, contains details of the tests, and describes the various ways the test results were and could be analyzed. © 2015 The Chartered Society of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Blind testing; Bullet and cartridge case comparison; Fake cases; Proficiency test
Correspondence Address: Article; bullet; controlled study; firearm; Netherlands; questionnaire

Title: Empirically determined frequency of error in cartridge case examinations using a declared double-blind format
Affiliations: California Department of Justice, Bureau of Forensic Services, Redding Regional Crime Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stroman, A., California Department of Justice, Bureau of Forensic Services, Redding Regional Crime Laboratory, United States
Author Keywords: Although the discipline of firearm and tooI mark identification has been accepted by courts since the early 20th Century, it has come under serious criticism from scientific and legal experts over the past several years. One of these criticisms is that the forensic science community, and the field of firearm and tool mark examination in particular, has not done enough to control bias in empirical research, such as participating in blind testing. Numerous examples of firearm and too! mark validation studies can be found in the relevant scientific literature. Many of these are single-blind studies involving the use of consecutively manufactured tools. A literature search of the AFTE Journal archives revealed only two studies that involved declared double-blind testing of firearm and tool mark examiners. The goal of this study was to empirically determine the frequency of error in firearms identification results produced by qualified examiners who were presented with realistic samples using a declared double-blind testing format. © 2014, Copyright Association of Firearm and Tool Mark Examiners-April.
Index Keywords: Bias; Blind testing; Breech face marks; Cartridge case; Declared testing; Double-blind; Empirical study; Error; Manufacturing processes; Null hypothesis; Proficiency tests; Reliability; Scientific method; Single-blind; Smith & Wesson 4006TSW pistol; Subclass characteristics; Validation study

Title: The Use of near-infrared photography to image fired bullets and cartridge cases
Affiliations: Crime Laboratory, Houston Police Department, 1200 Travis Street, Houston, TX, United States; Department of Forensic Science, College of Criminal Justice, Sam Houston State University, Huntsville, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stein, D., Crime Laboratory, Houston Police Department, 1200 Travis Street, Houston, TX, United States; Yu, J.C.C., Department of Forensic Science, College of Criminal Justice, Sam Houston State University, Huntsville, TX, United States
Author Keywords: An imaging technique that is capable of reducing glare, reflection, and shadows can greatly assist the process of toolmarks comparison. In this work, a camera with near-infrared (near-IR) photographic capabilities was fitted with an IR filter, mounted to a stereomicroscope, and used to capture images of toolmarks on fired bullets and cartridge cases. Fluorescent, white light-emitting diode (LED), and halogen light sources were compared for use with the camera. Test-fired bullets and cartridge cases from different makes and models of firearms were photographed under either near-IR or visible light. With visual comparisons, near-IR images and visible light images were comparable. The use of near-IR photography did not reveal more details and could not effectively eliminate reflections and glare associated with visible light photography. Near-IR photography showed little advantages in manual examination of fired evidence when it was compared with visible light (regular) photography. © 2013 American Academy of Forensic Sciences.
Index Keywords: Bullet; Cartridge case; Firearms; Forensic science; Infrared photography

Authors: Giverts P., Hocherman G., Bokobza L., Schecter B.
Title: Interdetermination of three microscopic methods for examination of striae on polygonal bullets
Affiliations: Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Giverts, P., Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Hocherman, G., Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Bokobza, L., Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel; Schecter, B., Division of Identification and Forensic Science (DIFS), Israel National Police HQ, Jerusalem, Israel
Author Keywords: Three different types of comparison macro/microscopes were used to examine and compare barrel striae impressions on projectiles. The principles and potentials of these three different microscopes are discussed and examined on the study of examples of polygonal rifled bullets.
